name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Colleagues, I would like to pay tribute today to a great man. On Saturday, Michel Rocard passed away at the age of 85. Death will have been the result of the bubbling of ideas and the constant commitment of our former colleague. Europe was one of his struggles and he demonstrated fully, by sitting in Strasbourg from 1994 to 2009, his commitment to free software, thus proving that Parliament and its members are committed to the divisions with tenacity, for a just cause, at the service of citizens. I remember more personally the tireless debater whose parliamentary office was next to mine. Despite being a former Prime Minister, he presented himself as a mere Member of Parliament and won the admiration of his colleagues for his work and personality, before becoming successive chairman of the Committees on Development, Employment and Culture. France loses a great European. She also loses a great statesman. We remember in particular the Matignon agreements, which helped to find a solution to the violence in New Caledonia. His commitment to environmental advocacy, particularly in the Arctic and Antarctic, confirms his high visionary quality. The French nation will pay tribute to him on Thursday. I ask you, ladies and gentlemen here in Strasbourg, to stand up and pay tribute to him today. (The Assembly, standing, observes a minute's silence)

The so-called Islamic State has pledged to carry out attacks in Turkey, Yemen, Bangladesh and Iraq. In these places, more than 300 people were killed and more than 500 others injured in a few days. Among the victims are men, women, some of them children, soldiers and civilians, people of various backgrounds, with different religions and nationalities. The international terror of this group makes no difference. He is blind and attacks everyone. name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow we will vote at first reading on the agreement reached with the Council on 6 April on the regulation on emission limit and type-approval requirements for internal combustion engines for non-road mobile machinery. This new regulation for non-road mobile machinery will replace the existing directive, cover all types of internal combustion engines installed on different types of machinery, which include small portable equipment, construction machinery, generators, motor vehicles and locomotives, inland waterway vessels, agricultural machinery, such as cotton harvesting machines, and narrow tractors. New power bands and new types of machinery such as cranes have been included in this regulation, for example in relation to the old regulation.  I have to say that work on this dossier has been long and demanding and it has also taken 6 trialogues – 4 with the Luxembourg Presidency and 2 with the Dutch Presidency – to reach this agreement. But I believe that we have reached a good agreement, indeed a very good agreement. The work was lengthy because the dossier was technical but also because we had to wait for the conclusion of other dossiers, such as the regulation on emissions under real driving conditions and the interinstitutional agreement 'Better lawmaking'. But in the end the co-legislators did an excellent job and I would like, of course, in addition to the Council and the Commission, to thank all my fellow shadow rapporteurs from the other political groups for this fruitful cooperation which we have been able to establish from the outset, and I believe that the sign of how fruitful this cooperation has been was also the vote in the ENVI Committee. , where our work received almost unanimity. Thanks to this fruitful work, I believe, we have also obtained a negotiating package where Parliament's priorities are clear and I believe that they have improved the Commission's original text.  I would also like to thank my colleagues in my group who supported me in my role as rapporteur and the chairman of the ENVI Committee, Giovanni La Via, for their support in the final trialogues and, of course, also all the staff of all the institutions involved in the work, because they had to do a great deal of work, precisely because of the technicality of the dossier. I would also like to express these thanks with a rather melancholy vein because, over and above the fact that we have worked at the turn of various presidencies which we are greeting right now – the Dutch Presidency to welcome and thus wish the Polish Presidency well in its work – I would remind you that two of the shadow rapporteurs who have worked with us are British, and therefore on this point. , so to speak, there is the melancholy of the vote of 23 June.  I think that the final agreement is extremely positive and I explain why: very briefly, without going into technicality, because I want to leave time for the debate perhaps to reserve a few minutes to reply and then conclude. I believe that we have found a truly important balance between protecting the environment and protecting the competitiveness of European industry. In fact, we in Europe will have the strictest emission limits in the world from 2019: we are talking about nitrogen oxide emissions, particulate emissions, therefore air pollutants responsible for 15% of emissions globally in this sector.  That is why I repeat the importance of the Rules of Procedure and also of tomorrow's vote.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) and warmly congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Gardini, for her hard work on this file, which made it possible to find a satisfactory compromise and to swiftly adopt the regulation at first reading. A fairer and deeper single market should also care about environmental protection and health. This regulation demonstrates that the Commission is delivering. In simple terms, this new regulation has two main goals: cutting emissions and cutting red tape. The new regulation provides for more stringent limits for pollutant emissions for engines installed in non—road mobile machinery. At the same time, it sets out harmonised rules for the EU markets and aligns with international standards. In this way, it is good for the environment and good for jobs and growth. It is thus not surprising that this proposal received – and still receives – broad support from the entire stakeholder community. Member States count on it to fulfil their obligations on air quality targets, industries rely on it to increase their competitiveness and to gain investment and legal certainty, and social partners and NGOs call for it to improve workers’ health and to protect the environment. Last but not least, the European citizens deserve it as they can legitimately expect their health to be protected to the best extent possible. Indeed, engines installed in non-road mobile machinery contribute significantly to air pollution and account for roughly 15% of the nitrogen oxides and 5% of the particulate matter emissions in the European Union. Recent studies indicate that their relative contribution to total NOx emissions could become bigger over time if nothing is done. The Commission has acted to propose stricter emission limits, resulting in a very significant emission reduction overall. The new regulation addresses the major air pollutants: nitrogen oxides, hydrocarbons, carbon monoxide and particulate matters, including limits for the so-called ultrafine particles, taking up the most recent conclusive evidence on their adverse health effects. Let me also address briefly an important aspect for the internal market: jobs and growth. With this regulation the competitive position of European industries is strengthened in many regards: additional business potential through access to a genuine European internal market, reduced costs through reduction of administrative burden and new business opportunities through harmonising technical requirements, which give industry access to other important world markets such as the US and Japan. In this way the regulation contributes to maintaining a leader position in the field of technologies through the supply of products of highest quality standards. Hence, in this way we lay the foundations to create more jobs and boost growth. The adoption of this regulation will have a positive effect on the environment and on health, as well as on entrepreneurship and competitiveness in Europe and this is, of course, good news.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, as a matter of solidarity I am going to address my speaking points on behalf of my colleague Seb Dance, whose flight has unfortunately been delayed. I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for all their work on this important file. Emission limits for non-road mobile machinery (NRMM) might not sound like the sexiest subject, but it is an important piece of the jigsaw when it comes to tackling air pollution.  In cities, non-mobile machinery such as construction equipment on building sites, trains and generators can significantly contribute to air pollution in the EU, and NRMM contributes around 15% of total NOx emissions and 5% of total PM emissions. These harmful emissions are linked to low birth weights, asthma, pulmonary heart disease, strokes and a variety of cancers, and are estimated to cause 50 000 premature deaths across the UK alone every year, and 10 000 in London.  This proposal is a perfect example of how trade in a common market can also deliver environmental and health benefits for citizens. Rather than allowing manufacturers to undercut each other in a race to the bottom on environmental standards, these ambitious and binding measures on NRMM will ensure industry is manufacturing progressively cleaner engines for these machines, which will go a long way to cleaning up toxic air pollution in the EU. Of course, should a post-Brexit UK want to remain a part of the EU common market, which many proponents of Brexit have said they support, the UK manufacturers will continue to be bound to these same rules, but without any national democratic representation having a say on how these rules are made. The inconvenient truth for those who sought to argue the environmental benefits of a Britain outside the EU is that air pollution has an unfortunate habit of not respecting borders. Over one third of the UK’s air pollution is blown in from across the English Channel.  Cross-border cooperation and common laws across European countries will be crucial – whether Britain is part of the EU or not – in ensuring we do not end up with a race to the bottom on environmental standards. Any new regulations in the UK must reflect this reality.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, reducing polluting emissions requires constant efforts and transformation of our productive devices. The report before us tends towards that goal and some of the means proposed are good. However, this text is much more restrictive than the current regulations and will leave even less room for manoeuvre for the Member States. We cannot continue on this path at a time when Europe is increasingly at a standstly age and our industrial activities are at half-mast. Despite this, the EU is strengthening a regulatory stranglehold that chains manufacturers or pushes them to circumvent legislation. In addition, the transition period beginning in 2018 and ending in 2020 is too short. Smaller producers will have great difficulty transforming their models and will live in fear of new texts hindering their medium- and long-term projects. Worse still, under the guise of harmonization and better market surveillance, the report accelerates the alignment of our standards with U.S. standards. But what can we hope for, ladies and gentlemen? That by doing so, we will increase the opportunities for our industries across the Atlantic? Come on, a little realism in a context of social crisis, economic stagnation over several decades and trade war. Let's not shoot ourselves in the foot! Let our builders breathe and turn our eyes first to research and investment! This is a positive and constructive vision of environmental policy, this is the true European pooling of our resources, the opposite of technocracy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, there is no doubt that the will of the majority of citizens is to drastically reduce gas emissions within the European Union and to establish strict upper limits. text: – Mr. President, I would like to emphasize right from the beginning that we have a typical example here of a win-win and another additional win combination because on the one hand we have a clear message of environmental protection and that is the first win. Secondly, we finally have one very strong regulation that wants to protect health and that's another win. We have a third, which is: we intend to enable a more competitive economy within the European Union and on the world market.  That is why I strongly support this report, which is why ALDE will vote for this report and we are confident that this regulation finally positions us properly. We must remain as European Union leaders in environmental protection, the health of our fellow citizens and of course in the competitive economy of our Member States and our entire economy and single market.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, I share the report’s attempt to strike a reasonable balance between the health and environment concerns and the competitiveness of EU industry, manufacturing and jobs. But we should be aware that despite the improvements in the last decades air pollution remains a major concern. Several EU urban areas do not meet the air quality standards and will not meet them in the foreseeable future. The challenge before us is the capacity of making environmental legislation being seen as an economic opportunity. In this sense I really hope this proposal will contribute to the competitiveness of European industry, particularly for non-road mobile machinery suppliers and I hope it will enable them to reap the full benefits of the internal market and to help EU enterprises to be more successful both here and abroad.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I have listened carefully to your exchanges and your comments and I would like to thank you for your contributions to this important debate. The proposal that is now on the table takes into account most of the concerns expressed by Members at the different stages of this legislative process. Let me thank the rapporteurs once again for cooperating so closely and thank Mrs Gardini for her efforts in closing the gap with the other co—legislator with her compromise solutions. Thanks also go to the shadow rapporteurs and the members of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO). In closing, let me stress a few key points. This new regulation will certainly reduce pollutant emissions for engines installed in non-road mobile machinery, a very positive step for the environment and the health of European citizens. In setting out harmonised rules for the European markets and aligning with international standards, it will promote competitiveness and clear red tape. Replacing the directive by a regulation will make life less burdensome for engine and machine manufacturers. From now on, they only need to look at one text and not at 28 national transposition laws. I may therefore recommend this regulation to the Parliament and call for your strong support. Thank you very much for your attention and even more for your work.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, very briefly, I believe that the debate we have witnessed has been a kind of small summary of the very thorough discussions we have had all these weeks and months. With Eickhout there is a relationship that has also become quite joking. When you tell me, Bas, the machines that collect cotton, we talk about 200 machines that work a few weeks a year, we know that. But, as you said, it makes a certain impression, but it's there.  I believe that this debate really represents the great effort, the great work that has been done and an example of how, by pooling our energies, listening to us and trying to achieve the common goal of improving the quality of the environment, of protecting the health of citizens, of making all possible efforts in the real world, we arrive at a result that is ultimately the best. They say that the best is the enemy of the good: for good we have achieved it, for the better we are equips ourselves with the next revision of the regulation, because small and medium-sized enterprises certainly have a wider transition period, because they will have much less bureaucracy, because there are so many positive points, in many respects and, I repeat, we will have the strictest limits in the world , because the other two most regulated markets, japan and the Us, will also lag behind the European Union.  Then we also introduced a new monitoring system to assess engine performance in real life, which will therefore close the gap between laboratory engine testing and real-world emissions, and we have also included – this is a technical thing, but we understand each other – thanks also to the interinstitutional agreement on better regulation, a substantial number of delegated acts. That is why, for this reason too, I believe that Parliament's role will be strengthened, another point that I am in favour of.  I would like to thank everyone once again: I would also like to thank Commissioner Thyssen and I hope that tomorrow we will have a large majority in support of this, which – I repeat – I find a great step forward for everyone: for the environment and health, but also for our industries and their competitiveness.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday, July 5, 2016. I would also like to congratulate the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs, whom I will also congratulate tomorrow, as I will be chairing the vote.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am sincerely honoured to have the opportunity today to present my report, on social inclusion and the integration of refugees into the labour market, in this House. This is clearly a very serious issue, which is one of the most complex challenges to which we are called upon to respond.  I will not conceal from you that I have approached the drafting of the document with some apprehension, fully aware of the complexity and importance of the subject. That is why I would like to begin my presentation by extending my sincere thanks to my fellow shadow rapporteurs for their extraordinary contribution to the drafting of the text, especially for their excellent cooperation throughout the parliamentary work. Only the ENF Group has been opposed to our work, the group of Marine Le Pen and Matteo Salvini, which, for a change, is not even present in this House now, when we talk about an issue such as refugees, which is often over-talked about on television.  As the European Parliament, we are called upon to present an analysis of the situation, policies and practices for integrating refugees into the labour market and into society. In drawing up the document, I based my reflection on some of the starting assumptions. For example, the fact that all humanitarian migrants are people forced to leave their country and are therefore an extremely vulnerable group. I have highlighted the current state of health of the European economy, which is still trying to emerge from a serious and protracted period of crisis, with record levels of unemployment, particularly among young people. I have pointed out that all too often the public and political debate on support measures to be given to refugees and asylum seekers is poisoned by false myths, prejudice and discrimination, various forms of populism and, at worst, racism.  Allow me to list a few key points in the report. Granting refugees access to the labour market is necessary to restore their human dignity and self-esteem, as well as being an effective measure in terms of public costs, as it allows them to be self-sufficient and achieve economic independence. Intervening with social and work inclusion policies in a timely manner is essential to enable these policies to succeed. In addition, labour market conditions in host countries are a key factor in the success and sustainability of refugee integration. The Commission and the Member States must therefore continue to give priority to policies and investments aimed at creating jobs and generating economic growth.  Integration and inclusion measures in favour of refugees and asylum seekers cannot and must not take away financial resources already allocated to programmes for other disadvantaged groups, but instead require additional social investment: it would be a serious political mistake and would create competition between the weakest, which would only lead to further social injustice. It is therefore necessary to bring the European Social Fund back to 25% of the cohesion policy budget; the reception conditions directive must be amended, allowing applicants for international protection access to the labour market within six months of the date of submission of the asylum application; we need to increase the public investment available and provide additional financial resources for local, regional public administrations and civil society and voluntary organisations. It is these who are at the forefront of the reception of refugees in our society and therefore deserve adequate support as well as greater recognition in policy-making.  Therefore, I hope that the House will be able to support the report voted on in the Committee on Employment, which I believe can be a useful document in identifying the social and employment integration of refugees as a challenge, but also an opportunity for our society, our economy and our European Union. I will be happy to answer your questions and comments.

name: Julie WARD
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague, Brando Benifei, for his work as rapporteur, and Silvia Costa for coordinating the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. Education is the key to both economic and social inclusion of refugees and asylum seekers, in particular young people, and that is why the Committee on Culture has put forward the notion of education corridors, and why it calls for further supporting the cooperation between EU universities and universities in places of conflict to ensure that children and young people who have to flee their country can pursue their education , which is a human right. It is not only important for welcoming countries, who will benefit from the economic contribution of educated newcomers, but it is also a moral and human duty for European societies to guarantee that these young people have the opportunity of a brighter future. I also want to highlight the role of informal learning, including lifelong learning, sport, volunteering, culture and the arts, which – by providing spaces for intercultural dialogue and exchange – not only facilitate the social inclusion of refugees into their new communities, but also address stereotypes, prejudices and discrimination by the majority. Too often, the dominant narrative says that somebody else is always to blame for the world’s problems. This results in a culture of fear. But when people come together and talk honestly and share in each other’s culture they learn that we are all human beings with common aspirations and concerns.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Benifei, and of course also the associate rapporteur of the CULT Committee, Mrs Costa, for the report, which provides valuable recommendations for us and Member States. Many of these recommendations have already been taken into account, which proves that we share the same concerns and that we are on the right track. Two weeks ago we organised a thematic event on measures to support the integration of asylum seekers and refugees in Brussels. The rapporteur was also present there. I think we all share the view that, not only do we have a moral duty as a society to welcome these people who are fleeing wars or other situations of extreme pressure in their countries, but also, from an economic point of view, the cost of non-integration would be much higher than the investments in integration. It is clear that the ongoing refugee crisis has put the European Union and its Member States to a test. Beyond meeting the immediate needs of refugees, it is essential to promote their integration in the host society and in the labour market. We know that the integration challenge comes at a point when Europe is recovering from a prolonged crisis with the impact still being felt on large parts of our societies. Mainstreaming the integration of refugees should be an integral part of our efforts for better coordinated and more inclusive social education, labour market and health policies in the European Union. It is about offering meaningful opportunities for all to participate in society and in the economy so it is not about taking from Peter to pay Paul. While integration is of course a Member State’s competence, the European Union has an important role to play in providing support to them. We promote the exchange of good practices to ensure early integration and facilitate the better use of available European funding. I am pleased to note that many of the points stressed in your report were also reflected in the Action Plan on Integration of Third-Country Nationals, adopted on 7 June, as you know. I refer in particular to the notion of a multidimensional and two-way approach to integration. I also welcome the focus on early and effective access to the labour market, vocational and language training, education, and basic services such as, for instance, healthcare and housing. Early integration into vocational training can provide third—country nationals with the basis for successful integration into the labour market and progression towards a high level of qualification. Refugees come with a diversity of skills and they can contribute to our economies. I welcome that your report highlights the need for better assessment of formal and informal skills and recognition of third—country qualifications. This step is important to releasing and employing the potential of third-country nationals. As I presented to you on 7 June, the Commission has put forward the New Skills Agenda for Europe and this Skills Agenda has specific provisions to address this challenge. In particular, in the context of the Skills Agenda, we have proposed the following specific elements: improving transparency of third-country qualifications through the division of the European Qualifications Framework; supporting frontline services and identifying and documenting the skills and qualifications of refugees through the launch of the skills profile tool for third—country nationals; promoting the upskilling of low skilled third—country nationals to the proposal for a Council recommendation establishing a skills guarantee; and assuring that better information about qualification recognition practices in different countries is collected through the new Europass framework. Furthermore, let me mention the Blue Card Directive, which aims to attract highly skilled third—country nationals to the European Union to work. In the revision of the directive the Commission has also proposed to open it to highly skilled beneficiaries of international protection. I know that the Parliament had been advocating in favour of such a measure. As I mentioned earlier, the Commission has a key role to play in facilitating the use of available EU funding. I welcome that your report acknowledges the Commission’s efforts to simplify and increase synergies among the available funding instruments. Furthermore, I take note of the fact that your report advocates for introducing a minimum share of 25% of the cohesion policy budget for the European Social Fund in the revision of the MFF in order to ensure adequate resources for labour market integration. However, this cannot be taken on board at this stage as it will necessitate a revision of the cohesion policy legislative package. As regards the ESF and field resources, we consider that relevant programmes are broad enough to accommodate the needs of refugees, but we stand ready to swiftly process reprogramming requests should these be made by the Member States. I welcome that your report also stresses the importance of better analysis and enhanced knowledge in the realm of integration. For this reason, over the past months the Commission has reached out to its networks of experts and stakeholders, Eurostat and partner organisations. We exchanged views on the collecting of data, on the outcomes of third—country nationals and how to map the implementation of the relevant policies across Member States. We also organised peer-learning events and activities involving different stakeholders such as the ESF managing authorities, the public employment schemes, network and civil society, to see various perspectives. In its action plan the Commission announced that it will reinforce exchange of practices notably to a revamped European integration network. The European website on integration is already a Europe—wide platform for networking on integration, supporting exchanges about policies and practices, but to facilitate mutual learning in tackling the challenges of the refugee crisis we have also developed an online database of promising practices, especially for the integration of asylum seekers and refugees. To conclude, investing in integration policies today will contribute to a more prosperous, cohesive and inclusive society in Europe in the long run, and I am pleased to see this view is reflected in your report, as well as in the recent Commission initiative.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the It was a hard piece of work to create 36 compromises out of 377 amendments. On the part of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I would like to thank Brando Benifei for his constructive cooperation. The hearing that we had – well staffed – was worthwhile and the months of intensive negotiations paid off. We want today's refugees and asylum seekers not to become the long-term unemployed of tomorrow. We want early intervention to prevent social isolation. This requires that the skills and knowledge acquired at home be reviewed and improved. In many EU Member States, we already have exemplary performance through small and medium-sized enterprises that offer traineeships. Learning the language in the host country plays a key role in finding your way around everyday life and in the world of work. This also avoids exclusion, ghettoisation and parallel societies. It is up to the Member States themselves to decide how the courses are designed, whether mandatory as in Germany, or voluntarily. We have agreed to reject the establishment of special labour markets for refugees. However, the national minimum wages must also apply to them and must not be stopped. Instead of setting up a new fund, we already have the AMIF, the EUR 3 billion fund for asylum, migration and integration. The use of the European Social Fund is controversial. I know that the current budgetary rules do not make it possible to increase from 22 to 25 per cent. Nevertheless, I am in favour of sending out a signal, if not immediately, then as soon as possible. How long will it take for refugees to have access to the labour market? In some Member States the waiting period is three months, in others six, in others nine. So there is a highly sensitive issue on the agenda and we cannot have a one-size-fits-all solution. That is why respect for the principle of subsidiarity is particularly important. Incidentally, I am in favour of accepting this report, which is so important, by a large majority. I hope that the PPE and others will follow this idea.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Those who flee war, persecution and torture must be integrated into the labour market as quickly as possible in their new homeland in order to be able to build their own existence, a new existence. The Member States must do their homework here, because if they do not make this integration into the labour market, then there will be social consequences. It saves costs if we quickly integrate people who come to us into the labour market by achieving their economic independence. It is also very important for the S&D Group that there should be no special labour markets with cheap jobs for refugees, who then compete with the unemployed at home. This creates social unrest, and then takes advantage of rights and right-wing populists. It is certainly very important that we preserve this equality. It is also important for us that local authorities, local authorities and those who work on the local part to integrate people are actually supported financially. I would like to thank Brando Benifei for an excellent report with many homework that our Member States will then have to take to heart.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – The current asylum crisis calls for a vision for the integration of refugees. Unfortunately, the report is in favour of an approach that is not sufficiently balanced.  Let me first of all stress that integration must be a story of rights and obligations. After all, governments need to invest heavily in the integration of refugees, so it is only natural that they should expect commitment to this. Only when both parties take their responsibility can integration succeed.  Secondly, and subsequently, I defend the principle that social rights must be built up. We must dare to think about this if we are to guarantee the sustainability of our social security. Credulity would allow us to bring down social protection in Europe. Thirdly, I do not believe that asylum can be a solution to Europe's ageing population. Asylum cannot solve structural internal economic shortcomings and legal migration cannot solve the asylum crisis either. So I do not support a revision of the Blue Card Directive, which mixes asylum and migration. Asylum and migration are two completely different issues that need to be dealt with separately.  Finally, I would like to say that a flexible labour market can contribute to the rapid integration of refugees.

name: Renate WEBER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur for his work, his dedication to this topic of utmost importance and his constructive approach during the negotiations. The text that we are discussing today is the result of hard work and compromise by the vast majority of this House and this attitude speaks for itself. There is no place for petty political arrangements or a populist agenda when it comes to refugees and their integration into our society. Not prioritising today would meet not only indifference but also irresponsibility for our society in the future.  We should not spare any efforts to ensure a proper social, cultural, linguistic and economic integration of refugees, and we have many reasons to do so. The first should be an understanding of the phenomenon, keeping in mind that we Europeans are what we are today as a result of different waves of mass migration. The second one should be humanity. No one under any circumstances wants to live in war. No one wants to leave their homes, families and countries and undertake an exhausting and dangerous journey if they can choose otherwise. It is an act of pure despair and we Europeans should stand by our values of humanity and tolerance.  The third one is the fact that the integration of refugees is beneficial not only to them, but to our society as well. In the long run, we could compensate demographic the challenges facing our continent, and through recognition of existing skills, language, educational and vocational training, we would be able to match supply and demand on our labour market. Therefore, I hope that the report will be voted tomorrow by a large majority of this House, thus sending the right message.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank rapporteur Brando Benifei and the shadow rapporteurs of this report for hopeing to be a step forward in social inclusion and labour integration of refugees in Europe.  For our group, ensuring access to housing, education and training, social protection, health and family reunification are indispensable pillars that cannot be questioned, because if we do so we would be questioning international law itself, the Geneva Convention and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and, therefore, our own principles and values.  Increasing public investment with an increase in the European Social Fund is good news, as is ensuring that refugees can access the labour market no later than six months after the application and have a minimum wage comparable to other Europeans and Europeans, avoiding social dumping and exploitation of the most vulnerable people.  We must, however, avoid generating pernicious dynamics promoting the reward of refugees against others on grounds of origin or formation: there can be no first- and second-rate refugees; and to do so, there needs to be measures to prevent discrimination— also gender discrimination in the labour market.  The 'Agreement of Shame' between the European Union and Turkey has been a dire and false step. We must go back, focus on designing integration and social inclusion policies and always expanding the welfare state, because without it there is no integration possible.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I too would like to thank the rapporteur for the very good work he has done on this report, involving all of us. The common European asylum system is absolutely clear on issues around access to the labour market and the rights that go with it. It was a key point when we were renegotiating the Qualifications Directive two or three years ago, and of course the possibilities in that regard in the Receptions Directive. We have a wealth of experience in Member States dating from the Equal Programme and, indeed, beyond that. And for those who talked about integration being a two-way process: that is true. One of the conclusions from the Equal Programme was that integration starts on the day of arrival for asylum seekers, and the day before arrival for receiving countries. It is important, as others have said, for local and regional government and other institutions to have additional resources – additional, not replacing existing training for host communities, but in order to take account of the special needs of those arriving. That investment in people is crucial, and it certainly repays in many ways. Language acquisition and access to education are crucial and we know this can be a real challenge for teenagers and adults who may have had disrupted, or no, access to education. However, we should not undo the good work in terms of training opportunities by issuing perpetual short-term residence permits, which are a problem both for the individual and for employers. We need to take that into account when looking at the asylum system.

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in thanking my colleague Brando Benifei for the work he has done and the cooperation he has sought, I recognise that addressing this issue was by no means easy, because Europe is the one that meets with african states in Valletta and proposes a holistic approach, but it is also a Europe that creates walls, barbed wire and prevents this acceptance in the sharing of responsibilities, and I am pleased that , those which were firm points for the 5-star Movement have been included in this report.  We have asked for an analysis of the causes of immigration, in order to understand where we start and why we start and to be able, in some way, to tackle the problem at its root, as well as solidarity in responsibility, because it is only in sharing responsibility that we can tackle the problem of immigration, certainly not by denying this cooperation between states. We have called for legal avenues of access, such as a fair mechanism for the distribution and distribution of migrants. We have called for policies that have a vision, that address the emergency today, but that question what can be done in the future, more and better.  And perhaps I would have liked Mr Benifei – since Italy is his country like mine and is at the forefront of dealing with the emergency in an even more difficult context, because you know very well how much Italy suffers from the problems of unemployment and social tensions and difficulties – to say more and better that the countries most directly involved in primary reception should have been protected and supported more.  In this we have perhaps a bolder vision and we would have liked this vision to have been somewhat his too. But we will support this report.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I regret that I cannot congratulate anyone on this report, because this report unfortunately ignores the reality in Europe. Although one in five young people in the eurozone is already unemployed – one in two in Greece – refugees are now to be entitled to work permits. These are unskilled or largely unskilled people, many of them flocking to Europe for economic reasons. I still clearly have in my ear the cheers of Daimler CEO Zetsche, who dreamed of a new German economic miracle: because refugees are exactly the people you need and are looking for at Mercedes. The sobering reality: 54 refugees found work for the DAX companies, 50 at Deutsche Post. This is ridiculous, a mockery, with a refugee figure of one million in Germany. What's left about it? There will be low-wage jobs, social tensions will arise, and there will continue to be frustrated citizens who will turn away from the EU more than before.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – He said that the biggest challenge for the UNION today is to tackle the refugee crisis. No, the biggest challenge is stopping the migration. Because there is very little hope for the effectiveness of the treatment. For decades, we have heard that communities with different cultures live side by side harmoniously in a society. The multicultural society has failed. At the same time, we are now chasing another fantasy, the hope of full integration, that immigrants will be fully integrated into European society and culture. And what do we provide for that? Housing, education, training, social protection, health care. Where does an EU citizen get all this in a backlog of poorer regions? Anywhere. And how much is that? We have heard that anyone who does not want to accept the quota is obliged to pay EUR 250 000 per migrant. We know that this is not from the air, but it costs a migrant for five years. This is an invitation for migrants!

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: - Dear Colleagues, The report prepared by my colleague Benifei, with whom we have been able to cooperate excellently on disability, is in order to achieve very important objectives. Still, my impressions are very mixed. The biggest problem I see is that this report, which deals with migration issues, does not provide enough answers to our constituents. There are currently 21 million unemployed people in the European Union. Youth unemployment has fallen to a tragic level in some Member States. How do we explain to the citizens of the European Union that they are less important to us now when they propose to increase the European Social Fund by 3%? What we agree on, however, is that it is very important that the rights and obligations of immigrants arriving in the European Union are clear. There must be a clear distinction between economic migrants and refugees. The latter are indeed entitled to these services. It is also necessary to avoid the mistake of telling all the Member States of the European Union how to act. Because there are many parts of the report that fall exclusively within the competence of the Member States, or there is not yet a consensus among the Member States on this issue.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for It is not an easy task to promote a constructive integration policy in a social climate in which xenophobia and fear spread. I would therefore particularly like to thank Mr Benifei for this report, which has been very, very good and which I very much hope the whole of Parliament will fully support.  In our committee, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, we have stressed that work is the best way to establish ourselves and enter a new country. However, where and how you live while as an asylum seeker plays a very big role in this establishment. In this context, it must be necessary to speed up processes and order in order to ensure that asylum seekers are not caught up in exclusion or exploited in a black labour market.  With this report, Mr Benifei also stresses that we should use the European Social Fund to support the integration process and ensure that we do not end up in these difficult situations, where exclusion will be the only option. It is simply a question of using the fund to invest in a European future, and I also hope that we can be fully agreed on that.

name: Czesław HOC
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I have said many times that integration without assimilation is pure utopia and wishful thinking, all the more so in terms of the so-called multidimensional integration of refugees into the European labour market. In my opinion, Europe should first ask refugees the fundamental question: do you want, are you ready and do you commit to the legal order and general principles of the country you are coming to, and thus to respect labour law, culture, traditions and customs? Because if refugees do not follow the legal order and established customs, we will not ensure a fair and equal labour market. Thus, the sine qua non of any integration into the labour market is the assimilation of refugees and a concrete will, but two sides.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We are talking about refugees and their so-called social inclusion and integration in the labour market. We have a survey to read today in the FAZ. The FAZ surveyed the 30 most valuable German companies, the DAX companies. All together have a turnover of 1.1 trillion euros and 3.5 million employees. By June, these companies had hired a total of 54 migrants: Deutsche Post 50, SAP 2, Merck 2. This means that 27 DAX companies have not employed a single migrant, not even Daimler! After all, it was Mr Zetsche who last autumn spoke of the refugees as the basis for the next German economic miracle and said: that is exactly what we are looking for at Mercedes. And then he doesn't hire a single one of them, not even for the show. What an oath of revelation! The truth is that we do not expect an economic miracle, but an extreme burden on the welfare state, and we have not allowed skilled workers into the country, but at best motivated people who are not qualified and unqualified in our highly differentiated labour market, but who lack their skills in their home countries. We must face up to reality, and the reality is that refugees remain only for time. They do not therefore need to be integrated, even in the labour market. We help as many as we can, but we cannot help everyone. And migrants have to come through immigration law, not the right of asylum. We must protect our external borders. In other words, we need Fortress Europe. And then, in national law, we can create immigration rules and grant asylum precisely to those who need our help, and each country decides how much aid it may provide.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there are 22 million unemployed citizens and 122 million poor people in Europe. This is the reality that brings down the mask of the fake goodness of the left. There is no need for a new workforce in Italy and Europe. We don't need new immigrants. And then you just have to play with words and numbers: real refugees, real refugees, are only 30% of illegal immigrants arriving in Italy and the term refugee means that the person will return to his country of origin once the war is over. That is why the discussions on long-term integration are pointless.  You, invited immigrants to reach this Europe of poverty, of crisis, you are fools. We all know that the policy of open doors for all will lead to the death of the peoples of Europe. Shame on you, because you're complicit in this lousy human business. You're not saving lives from poverty, but you're importing millions of new slaves. The truth is that the business of immigrants is playing into the hands of multinationals: so much new cheap labour that will reduce the wages of our citizens even further. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: blue card question. – Mrs Bizzotto, are you aware that millions of Italians migrated to Latin America seeking their future and hope throughout the 20th century that millions of Italians migrated to North America seeking their future and hope?  But are you aware, above all, that Italy is a founding country of the European Union, that it has signed the European Convention on Human Rights, the Geneva Convention on the Status of Refugees, and that there is nothing to do with the search for opportunities for an economic immigrant — which were millions of Italians, at the time — with the right to protection when one is persecuted in his country of origin?  Are you aware?

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Answer to a blue card question. I know this very well, because I come from a land, Veneto, from where so many people have left. My uncles emigrated abroad. I also know, however, that there are many unemployed people in Italy: there are people who struggle to get to the end of the month, there are the elderly who no longer have the money to buy medicines for treatment. So I, here in the European Parliament, want to defend them before the others, because we cannot save the world. I want to save and help my citizens.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). Madam President, the Union's supposed concern about the labour integration of refugees reveals neither its responsibility for their drama nor its objectives, it reveals its barbarity. Challenge refugee flows with its interventions, repression, refoulement of refugees in violation of refugee status. Closed borders, the firing of xenophobia, racism, fascism, the entrapment of thousands in the first host countries, which is also promoted by the report 'Using training'. Distribution of what and where they are needed, filling demographic gaps, labour shortages, squeezing them out like cheap labour force, pushing further the general level of wages, generalising flexible employment. The report literally provokes, praising the contribution of taxes from refugees to their daughters' coffers.  The main thing is: the promotion of refugees in their countries of destination with recognition of refugee status, labour integration with full rights of those who choose to stay where they are today, direct support for the education and employment of refugee children under the responsibility of the state and not of NGOs that are scalding huge funds. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, Mr President, I would like to thank the previous speakers for their excellent work and for the way in which So you have entered the mainstream and said that refugees are oppressed in Europe, that refugees are being treated badly. I do not know which countries you are talking about – I do not know all of them – but do you happen to know that in my country, Austria, a refugee can receive between EUR 500 and 800, depending on the region, but also – if he has many children – up to EUR 1000? I do not know which Europe you are talking about. However, I believe that what you are saying is wrong, and I do not want to hear an answer, that in my own country, for example, refugees are not oppressed.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI), "blue card" answer. – First of all, I question the data you gave on the salaries of refugees in Austria. Secondly, I would remind you that Austria and other countries have put up fences at their borders so that no one can cross.  After all, the fact that refugees will be used as cheap labour is not just us; it is the invitation of Schäuble, Merkel, Moscovici and many others, the multinationals themselves, to use them as cheap labour force. The report itself admits this.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: – Madam President, this is a humanitarian crisis generated by war, which requires rapid and effective responses from us. Europe, founded on the ideal of peace, which has lived within doors of dramas in all similar things, has a duty to welcome human beings who try to escape death by asking us for help. Refugees are not economic migrants and we must raise our voice to disprove the extremist and xenophobic accusations that accuse those who fight for life of economic opportunism. But refugees, once in the Community, must respect our rules and our culture and become active contributors to the society of the Host Member State. This is an integration that must be based on the combination of rights and duties, ensuring equal treatment for European citizens. Access to the labour market is still a challenge for Europeans. We must ensure that newcomers have a successful social inclusion, and their integration into the European labour market is essential and should be complementary and not conflict with the internal situation. We need effective and transparent mechanisms for validating your skills, academic qualification and professional experience. At the moment, it is essential that we do not lose ourselves in bureaucracy, without neglecting, of course, our security. The moment requires consideration and requires the involvement of all Europeans, but also the personal effort of each of the welcomed.  The Commission has developed good initiatives to address this drama, bumping into the selfish and nationalist interests of many Member States. If this were an economic problem, it would have been solved long ago. We all have a lot of work to deal with this situation.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Thank you to the Commissioners and, above all, to my colleague Brando Benifei, who has written a fine report on an important subject, because in 2015 alone, more than 1.2 million people applied for asylum in Europe. Some were rejected. Many others were allowed to stay, but who knows for how long.  And all the while, people are on the sidelines of society, and that benefits no one. Not the refugees, who often do not have access to the labour market and therefore do not have access to society, and the Member States do not, which in this way encourage poor integration. We must therefore work on integration through language, training and training, so that refugees can participate in ordinary life and also use their new skills when they return to their country.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Angela Merkel said as recently as November 2015 that the German labour market is looking for skilled workers and that Germany is a rich country that can accommodate many people. It has already been mentioned today that of all DAX companies, only 54 refugees have been put into work. However, if every refugee or migrant who is not in work costs the German state EUR 25 000 a year, that is more than EUR 30 billion a year for around 1.3 million people. By way of comparison, the item for education and research in the federal budget amounts to approximately EUR 16 billion. Sure, there will be some employers hiring some refugees, but so far Merkel's vision for the job market looks like a complete fiasco. But if the German labour market does not make it, how will the Greek, Italian, Portuguese or French labour market manage? Our society, rich, according to Mrs Merkel, has rotting roads, ailing schools and bridges at risk of collapse. Unfortunately, there have been no financial resources for these matters in the last ten years.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Madam President, another report of ideas and ideas is coming up for debate in the European Parliament. Without yet specifying how many refugees and how many illegal immigrants there are and having left thousands stranded in Greece and Italy, with the closure of borders, you are incentivising Europe to flood even more migrants. Is someone so naïve as to believe that these people can join European society? Do you want to integrate them into the labour market when unemployment in Europe and especially in the countries of the South is galloping? Have you asked European citizens if they want them? It's a nice tale, but it's got a lot of dragons.  Those who have blooded Belgium, France and sown fear at airports, the metro and even sporting events and jobs have had their European education provided. But you have not been able to integrate them, because there is one factor that you refuse to admit: the religious hatred they have against us, because of religion and because of culture, and that prompts them to exterminate those they consider unfaithful.  Stop wars and interventions in third countries and seek to live in peace in their countries. Strengthen the institution of the traditional family in Europe in order to increase the workforce and, finally, let European citizens decide, not capitalists and appointed technocrats. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Julie WARD
text: blue-card question. – Do you realise that some of these ‘others’ that you refer to actually include Members of this House? A fellow MEP of mine from the northwest of England who has had an esteemed position as the Lord Mayor of Manchester, a policeman, is a Muslim, and sits in this House. And the offence that you make when you ‘other’ people is absolutely despicable, so how can you exonerate yourself from being so Islamophobic?

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), "blue card" answer. – When you say "others" I don't know who you mean, you may mean Muslims. I'm not talking about all Muslims, I'm talking about those fanatics who come to blood Europe. It is clear that you cannot control from these flows of illegal immigrants who are coming, who are coming to do harm in Europe and who are coming to escape the fire of war or want to bring the fire of war to Europe.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, we all agree that the integration of refugees is a crucial task at a time when there is a million-dollar wave of refugees in Europe and where we bear the fruits of failed integration in the form of ghettoisation, social exclusion and radicalisation. I believe that this is, above all, the task and interest of the Member States, which have different conditions but have the same interests in security and in the prosperity and dignity of all citizens.  Of course, from the level of the European Parliament, we can use common experience and, above all, support programmes. We must support the Member States in their efforts, to provide asylum seekers with access to education and, where possible, access to the labour market.  However, as the European Parliament, I would not want to order Member States to have faster access to the labour market for asylum seekers than the current directive allows. That is, shortening from nine to six months. That is what the Member States can do today, but we should not order them to do so.  I am also having trouble supporting the increase of the limit from 23% to 25% for the European Social Fund for the Integration of Refugees. The Commissioner has spoken positively and I would leave it to the European Commission. Of course, it is possible – and I even expect – that, when revising the Multiannual Financial Framework, the European Commission will decide to promote the inclusion of disadvantaged people, and migrants in particular. But it is up to the European Commission, why only 25% and why not 30%. Let the European Commission decide according to the needs and different conditions of the Member States.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, we have talked on many occasions about how we have failed in trying to ensure safe and legal access routes for those who were entitled to asylum in Europe. But without a doubt, the biggest challenge we have—the biggest challenge—is the integration of the more than a million people who have already arrived, and those who will come in the future. And, without a doubt, in order to integrate refugees, access to the labour market, quickly and effectively, is the spearhead of integration. Access to the labour market without discrimination, which is at the same time accompanied by education, recognition of its qualifications, access to language, and knowledge, social protection assistance or access to housing. And all this knowing that, in order to ensure that access to the labour market, we must combat labour exploitation and... people who do undeclared work, and we have to devote resources from across Europe, such as the European Social Fund, always bearing in mind that they are not detrimental to our needs. That's why this report by Brando Benifei is going in the right direction.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam President, the European Union has a moral and strong global actor and political obligation to help people who have fled to danger in our neighbourhood. But it is one thing to help according to opportunities, and it is something else entirely to ask citizens to fund privileged status for hundreds of thousands of newly arrived people in the long term. While some Member States still face economic challenges and are trying hard to stabilise public finances, taxpayers are obliged to fund all social rights, health services, education and even employment measures to a non-negtiable number of people. The refugees are people who have sought refuge from the war and will return to their home when the conflict in their country is finally over. The rest are migrants who have taken advantage of the chaos in the Middle East to improve their economic situation. It is natural that these people want a better life in Europe, they should not be judged for it, but different rules must apply to them.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her What are we talking about? We are talking about the social inclusion of refugees, we are talking about equal treatment for the unequal. When I read this report, I am no longer surprised why Brexit has come and why more and more people in Europe are despairing. Because when we hear the head of the German Federal Office for Migration and Refugees, Mr. Frank-Jürgen Weise, he assumes that around 10% of refugees are qualified for the labour market. Overall, he said, refugees are a burden on the labor market. Why is that? Plato, the Greek philosopher, spoke of a Zoon politikon, man is a political community. A community is founded by common origin, by common language, common culture, common historical experience and common citizenship, and you cannot justify this by taking language courses. It cannot be. It cannot grow together, which does not belong together. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Thomas MANN
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". – We have just learned the same thing from the far-right camp that far too few refugees are in the labour markets. Have you not listened to the debate? We have pointed out that we need to check what skills people have, the ability to integrate them into companies, and we want to review that. There are many internships for this. If you see how many internships have been successful here, you will also notice how many are involved in the work processes. This takes time, it cannot be done in a pig's gallop. Do you not also share responsibility for taking this time factor into account?

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I would, of course, like to thank you for this very interesting question. A time factor. Does Europe have a time factor? What is the time factor in Europe for the German unemployed, which one for the European unemployed, for the unemployed in Greece? We should first take care of our own unemployed before we take care of the strangers, who, as I said, are not equals, but unequal, because of the lack of a sense of community, and are therefore simply integrable.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: Madam President, what I hear here makes me change a little bit what I was going to say. I come from a country, from a region, where there is a coal mining that has experienced the greatest disaster, the Bois du Cazier: 262 dead, mostly Italians, but there were workers from just every country, including people from the Maghreb. They spoke different languages, they had different religions, but they were part of the same community, a community of human beings. I think that in this type of debate we must remember this and I think that the report before us today is an important, quality report, which puts essential issues at the centre of the debate. We cannot accept that this debate is polluted by ideas of rejection of the other, ideas - we must call them by name - which are racist ideas. I am therefore pleased to see a report that highlights the necessary integration of refugees. The sooner and the better they are integrated into the labour market, and the sooner they contribute to our society, the sooner they will add value to it, the sooner they will be integrated and better received. There cannot be two kinds of workers, two kinds of employees, they must be equal. I therefore call on both of them to support the very interesting elements in this report which show that the European Union can be an area of humanity.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Today we are discussing the social inclusion of refugees and their integration into the labour market. I would like to thank my group colleague Helga Stevens for her successful work on this report. As is so often the case in asylum debates, I have heard so much untruths, half-truths and exaggerations from both sides here in this Chamber this afternoon. We have heard about this from the German DAX companies and the FAZ. I share this criticism. However, please also mention those who have been doing something for months, mentions small and medium-sized enterprises and craftsmen, the local family businesses. They help refugees, they create internships, apprenticeships and jobs; this, too, should be emphasised. In my home region alone, I know of some businesses that are happy to rely on former refugees. Let's say who produces them: the middle class. They need more support. I call for a reallocation of ESF funds to the countries that mainly shoulder the flow of refugees and integration, money that mainly benefits small and medium-sized enterprises. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. Gerick, I have listened carefully to what, unlike your other clubmates and who come from the same country, you have been saying. In a special way, you talked about the need to support medium and small businesses in your region. I'd like to bring in another dimension that's been little talked about, and you kind of mentioned it.  I think it is very important to support regional, urban, local authorities that can help integrate refugees both in the labour market, but also in education and other systems. Do you agree with me?

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Yes, I agree with that. I have also emphasised this in such a way that we must support small and medium-sized enterprises in particular – these are the companies on the ground that do a great deal – but also only where there are really refugees. If support does not arrive there, then this support for refugees cannot succeed.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – The refugee crisis is also a crisis of today's politics, notwithstanding the time that the first refugee wave has been around for a very long time, we have not yet answered some basic questions. Namely, how many refugees can Europe help, and how many migrants does Europe have jobs for? There are no easy answers, of course, but running away from them will just not bring better solutions. Of course, we are a social Europe and we want and want to help all those fleeing war, but we must be realistic and, on the other hand, also be aware that there is no single recipe for the integration of refugees into the labour market. Because, of course, labour markets in individual countries are not the same, they need a new workforce somewhere, they have problems elsewhere because they themselves are too unemployed. If, of course, we are not able to separate the different situations of individual countries, I do not think that we will even be able to achieve this objective of actually helping those who are in need of assistance.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: – It should be emphasised that we are talking about refugees, that is, people who are fleeing war, who want to save their lives and their loved ones. So what happened today in Europe that more and more people are against not only immigrants, but against refugees? Why is xenophobic sentiment growing? Firstly, everyone who comes to Europe must accept and respect our European culture, traditions and European values. Without this, there is no chance of acceptance. Secondly, let us not forget that the European Union is facing high unemployment, immigration of its citizens. Europeans do not understand why their rights and social assistance are to be – or even sometimes are already – less than aid to refugees. It is difficult today for a good policy that fights against the social exclusion of refugees. However, without language learning, without educating refugees, especially women and children, without a sincere answer to the question: why are more and more Europeans against immigrants and refugees, without the understanding and acceptance of the people of Europe, every policy, even the best, is doomed to fail.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for While the European Union should have to contend with itself and think about how to get back on track, it has set itself another task, a Sisyphos task: social inclusion and integration into the labour market of so-called refugees. Well over a million of them came to Germany last year. Well, they have been enthusiastically welcomed, among others by the CEO of Daimler, Mr. Zetsche, who said literally: "Most refugees are young, well-educated and highly motivated – that is exactly what we are looking for." But that is the only thing he had to contribute to this, because to this day he has not employed anyone. In total, the 30 German DAX companies have now hired a whopping 54 refugees! Let's just compare this with the figures from New Year's Day on The Cologne station forecourt. There are now 183 perpetrators from the same group of people, namely the so-called refugees. This is what actual social inclusion and integration in Germany looks like at the moment. And if Mr Müller of Volkswagen AG, who should have completely different problems at the moment, now expresses his incomprehension for the AfD, then it only shows how little these two gentlemen are interested in reality.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, social inclusion and integration into the labour market was a problem in the European Union, and we must all recognise that this refugee crisis has caught us on the wrong foot. All the more important is this report, and I will support the report and I congratulate the young MEP for being able to manage such an important problem, with all the political groups, and to produce extremely important things. What worries me is that the Commissioner does not want, she has told us clearly, to take over some extremely important things. We cannot integrate refugees and people are people, they have no fault if we do not have budgets for job creation, for SME support, for research, because these people need jobs. I am outraged by the position of some MEPs, colleagues here, extremists, who treat people with different measures. I am part of a humanist party and I cannot conceive of leaving people suffering. I therefore propose that the Member States and the Commission establish precise rules for the integration of refugees into the labour market and that they have rules for compliance with European and national legislation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, it has so far been shown that the operation to integrate refugees and migrants has led to even higher unemployment, lower wages and the dissolution of the social state. When, last year, Germany's Committee of Wise Men proposed to set up hunger wages, supposedly to better integrate refugees and migrants entering Germany en masse, it aimed to chineseize wages in the European Union. As long as the countries of the European South are plagued by poverty and unemployment, refugees and migrants cannot enter the labour market.  That is why I have called for the distribution of refugees between Member States to calculate, in addition to GDP and population, both the rate of growth of the economy and the level of unemployment. Also, real integration means accepting and respecting the constitutional framework and laws of the host State and abandoning various antiquated social practices and perceptions.  Unfortunately, these issues are not addressed in the report, remaining ideological and superficial. This has already triggered a Brexit. Let us see what is done to change the European Union's course.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Given the large number of refugees who have made their way to the EU, their integration will be one of the most important issues over the next 10 to 15 years.  If we succeed in integrating these people, europe will be able to maintain its openness to the world and remain a continent with relatively little racism and xenophobia. If we fail, not only will we have problems with transparency, trade and growth, but we will also face a very dark future.  To succeed, much more needs to be more than just education. I am aware that what is required may be controversial. Some countries have to be forced to offer reasonable conditions, basic rights, arrange language courses; others to open up their closed labour markets, but let me put it this way: we have no choice.  It is only today's solidarity with those who are outside that can prevent and prevent tomorrow's problems. So, for once, let us do things on time and let us use europe's soft power to influence countries in the desired direction.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – We are therefore facing one of the most complex challenges of recent times, we are facing the biggest relocation since The Second World War and, of course, the integration of these people, refugees into society also depends on integration into the labour market. It is therefore necessary to support and open up new sources of funding that will encourage a greater and more active employment and integration policy for these groups of so-called humanitarian refugees. However, we cannot pass, of course, also erecting so-called educational bridges, because of course education is also one of the key elements for better inclusion. Of course, practices in countries are different, and I think we need to support and follow those practices that are positive, good. It is true, however, that the unemployment situation varies from European countries to different countries, which should be taken into account. Above all, it would be worst if refugees also became a category of permanently unemployed.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Dear Colleagues, The European Union seems to be simply refusing to learn the lessons of Brexit a few days ago. The vast majority of European citizens believe that migration must be stopped. Tragic life situations – poverty, wars and so on – must be remedied, rooted and dealt with on the spot or near the site. You can't export these things to Europe. You can call these people populists, you can call them extremists. But sooner or later, dear colleagues, people are going to rebel. Right, Commissioner? I look forward to your opinion on this. You can wait for one country to leave the Union after another. Your European Union will collapse like a house of cards unless you come to your senses and listen to the people.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: member of the Commission. Your rapporteur, Mr Benifei, has completed a very comprehensive and in-depth report, and I would once again like to thank him sincerely for that. Several of you have said it: there are more people on the run than ever before. These are people who seek protection from us, who see a beacon of hope in the European Union and who hope and count on our solidarity.  We have a legal and ethical duty to give that protection to those who are entitled to international protection, and I am personally convinced that it is best for everyone to integrate the people who receive protection as quickly and as well as it can, both in our society and in our labour market.  We all know that's not an easy task for anyone. The efforts must come from two sides. We live in a society of rights and obligations. That's the way our society works. But having said that, we also know that refugees are a group of very vulnerable people. If we look at their situation, of course they have traumas that some people have already spoken about, but we also know that they have qualifications that have been acquired elsewhere, qualifications that have been acquired elsewhere.
