It is often very difficult to compare their skills, if they are already documented, with what is needed in our labour market. They are often also low-skilled. We must give them the opportunity to learn and to develop basic skills. We try to do this with a number of elements of our skills agenda. We must give these people the opportunity to learn languages, which we have also included in our action programme for the integration of migrants. There are already a number of budgets in there that will be spent to give those people the opportunity to learn the language of the host country. I do not think we should deny that there is still pure discrimination in our society, including in our labour market. We must also oppose this, and we must also do something about it.  What are we doing from Europe? This semester we are looking at, among other things, the situation of migrants in the labour market. A number of Member States have received specific recommendations because they could perform better in terms of integrating people from migrant backgrounds, sometimes even the second or third generation. And that is also the case for countries other than those that have received specific recommendations. Furthermore, we are using everything we have at our disposal, because some of you have rightly said that it is primarily a task of the Member States. But we in Europe can help the Member States in this difficult task. We do that with everything we have at our disposal. We do this with our action programme for the integration of people from third countries. We do this with our skills agenda which contains a number of specific elements to increase the chances of integrating refugees. We do the same with our approach to the blue card.  We also use our funds: the European Social Fund and the FEAT are funds that can also be used for the integration of refugees and are used for this purpose. We exchange best practices and we ensure that there can be capacity expansion in the Member States. Because in this area too, our countries can learn from each other. We also use, once again, the instruments we have at our disposal during the semester. I was already referring to the country specific recommendations. However, I would also like to point out that the additional expenditure associated with this refugee crisis in the evaluation of the budgetary situation of the Member States is also effectively recognised as extraordinary and that these expenditures are not taken into account to see whether Member States are covered by an excessive deficit procedure. Dear Members of Parliament, integration of newcomers is not an easy task, not for the people who have fled the horror in their own country and who need to build a new community in a new Member State. Nor is it always easy for the people in the host Member State. But one thing is certain. We all have an interest in taking care of the people who come to us as well as possible and integrating them as well as possible into our society and in our labour market. And if we succeed, we can all benefit from it: economically, but the cohesion of our society can only benefit from that.  I would like to repeat the words of one of the Members who said earlier: 'It cannot be the intention to make it all the long-term unemployed.' I think that's something we don't want. So we have to go for the opposite and I am very grateful for all these recommendations and for the things we share to give those people the opportunity so quickly. possibly become integrated.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I would like to inform my fellow Members that Members who were unable to speak in the debate because this was not possible – we all know that a written statement of up to 200 words per session can be submitted, which will be attached to the literal minutes of the debate and constituted a speech.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank all my fellow Members for this in-depth debate and also Commissioner Thyssen for her participation and for the important words that have been spoken. On the one hand, it is clear that this is a very complex issue; there is a need to take a balanced approach, as we have said, we need to make choices in the direction of integration, which is integration not to the detriment of the inhabitants of the receiving countries, against social dumping, for truly real integration into the world of work and into the refugee society.  Thank you for the joint work and thanks to the Commission, as I said, for the clear words, I also respect, it is true, the clear progress that we see in the proposals of the Action Plan for third-country nationals, in the news skills agenda, indications and proposals that go in the direction of what the report calls for. So let us continue to work in this direction, with constructive work, as this debate in Parliament has been constructive, in order to find balanced solutions for everyone: for refugees and for citizens who have legitimate concerns and fears but who must be reassured in the Union's desire to build integration solutions that are useful for all, so that, as I said in my speech, we can , refugees, whose acceptance is our humanitarian duty, find their dignity and find meaning for a life that is often traumatised precisely in integration into our society.  At the same time, I am pleased that people who represent, for me, also for the things they say, the very ideas of racism and xenophobia, such as Mr von Storch and Mr Voigt, have been totally at a disagreement with this report, but their very racist words, in my opinion, qualify them themselves. And also my fellow Members, such as Mrs Bizzotto, who, in my opinion, has shown, as well as often my colleagues in the Northern League, that they do not read the reports because the concerns about social dumping ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Tuesday, July 5, 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: Written. – Recognition of qualifications, immediate start-up training, speeding up access to employment, fair working conditions, support for SMEs. By these means, we will get asylum seekers into the labour market and integration. Work is the best means of adaptation and integration, and it equally benefits the individual and society.  Asylum seekers must be allowed to work while the asylum application is being processed. In order to facilitate access to employment, we should better examine and recognise the qualifications and professional competences of refugees and asylum seekers. Small and medium-sized enterprises play a crucial role in the employment of refugees and asylum seekers. Public authorities shall provide smEs with comprehensive and tailored support and advice. At the same time, asylum seekers must be helped in every way to set up businesses. The national minimum wage and working conditions must apply to refugees in the same way as others. There is no reason for us to create our own labour market for refugees.  The MEMBERS of the EPP tabled amendments to the report during which the minimum wage would not apply to refugees or that refugees could be hired under one-day contracts and poorer working conditions. It is not a sustainable path, but creates a two-storey labour market that will lose both refugees and other workers.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. The European Union is only interested in the integration of "refugees" into the labour market, without seeking an alternative solution, even though immigration is a tragedy whose first victims are the immigrants themselves: an unprecedented number of deaths, poor housing or exploitation. The very notion of "refugees" remains more than ambiguous. There is still no concrete definition because while the EU differentiates three categories of 'legal beneficiaries', it does not give a real definition. Moreover, the EU recognises that this reception of refugees is a remedy for Europe's demographic problems: "the EU's working-age population is expected to decline by 7.5 million by 2020".  What a shame to think so when you see the unemployment figures! What a shame not to prefer a birth policy to mass immigration! The EU states that refugees "can undertake and generate economic activity that has a positive impact on host communities" without having any certainty or concrete figures. On the other hand, we are talking about integration but not assimilation. Integration implies "claim" and "communitarianism" where assimilation implies adaptation and recognition.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question on the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative (O-000094/2016 - B8-0709/2016) (2016/2793/RSP) on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs.

name: Thomas HÄNDEL
text: Author. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative are essential instruments for combating youth unemployment. We have initiated a lot to put an end to this misery, but the effect is still modest. I am convinced that more is urgently needed. Allow me, however, to comment on yesterday's interview. The German Finance Minister, Mr Schäuble, yesterday strongly criticised the Commission. If it is unable to solve problems quickly, national governments would have to take it into their own hands – without Brussels. The press has also interpreted this criticism to the Commission's work on youth unemployment. I am really the last person to make a saving by criticising the Commission. But it is not only on this issue that Europe's chief thrift apostle should take a look at his own. Those who are unwilling to give up the austerity in Europe that has driven some Member States into a situation where their budgets are barely able to act, should better refrain from bouty Brussels bashing. It is true that the elimination of youth unemployment is primarily a matter for the Member States, including those with lower youth unemployment. Schäuble is now proposing a European training network. The idea is not entirely new. Nevertheless, Commissioner Thyssen, the Commission should take him at his word, but also talk to him about a training fund in which the rich Member States in particular participate. He is meeting with initiatives that we have already discussed in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and which I personally started in Thuringia and Bavaria. What is clear is that EU levels can initiate, support and coordinate financially. However, the Member States must implement it. There is obviously a lack of that. It should be noted that the Member States launched a Youth Guarantee as early as April 2013: all young people should receive a high-quality job, training, further education or training within four months of leaving the school.  be offered an internship. The Youth Employment Initiative aims to support young people under the age of 30 in regions with particularly high levels of youth unemployment. In order to achieve greater impact, the financial resources have already been made available in the first two years of the medium-term financial framework. Substantial pre-financing was made available to Member States, which was increased to 30% in 2015. But paper is obviously patient. Youth unemployment is still unacceptably high. Something has happened, but too little and too slowly, and the regional differences are glaring. Opinions and reports from the European Court of Auditors, the Council of EU Labour and Social Ministers and the Member States are now available. We now need clear facts and foundations for the future path and for the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework. Can the Commission inform Parliament of the main results of the evaluations? Is the implementation of the Youth Guarantee Programmes correct? What is the quality of the offers and the sustainability of the results? Are the programmes and the use of funds on the right track? Has the increased pre-financing accelerated the absorption? How can access to funding from the Youth Employment Initiative and the ESF be accelerated and simplified? Does the Commission believe that further investment in the Youth Guarantee is needed and that the Youth Employment Initiative needs to be extended? I would like to reiterate here what I have said on several occasions: we are losing an entire generation, and an entire generation is losing faith in Europe. This is an existential question for the future of young people, but also for the future of the European Union. I don't think everyone has yet to see that.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, Europe is on a path to recovery. We see that employment figures continue to rise and that unemployment is starting to drop. But, as we all know, the effects of the crisis are still being felt in many Member States and regions, and young people in particular have borne the worst of it. Fighting youth unemployment remains a top priority for the Commission. Therefore, I want to thank Thomas Händel and the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs of this House for their question on the Youth Guarantee and Youth Employment Initiative. As you know, we have acted by adopting a solid policy framework on youth employment, the Youth Guarantee, and by dedicated funding to the Youth Employment Initiative for those young people not in employment, education or training. This funding comes in addition to substantial European Social Fund (ESF) intervention and on top of national funding, which is equally needed to fight youth unemployment. The Youth Guarantee is a driver for real reform. It is the central plank in our efforts to improve access pathways to the labour market and facilitate the transition from education to the job market, and it has already started to bring results. As regards the Commission’s findings on the Member States’ evaluations, it is important to stress that Youth Guarantee implementation has started in all Member States following the planning phase. In 2014 all the Member States presented their Youth Guarantee implementation plans, which identify precisely the measures to be taken to implement the Youth Guarantee. They outline the timeframe for youth employment reforms and measures, the roles of public authorities and other organisations and how the measures will be financed. The implementation of the national plans is now underway. Member States are making substantial efforts to implement the Youth Guarantee, which has proven to be a driver for structural reforms. The Joint Employment Reports for 2015 and 2016 list promising steps, with concrete examples in many countries. For example, Member States are strengthening their public employment services to improve the outreach to those furthest from the labour market. In addition, they are building closer partnerships with the private sector to increase the number and improve the quality of job offers, apprenticeships and traineeship opportunities. The Youth Guarantee has also accelerated progress on delivering the skills that employers are actually seeking. The substantial European financial support available underpins the successful implementation of the Youth Guarantee. Three years into its implementation, the Youth Employment Initiative, worth EUR 6.4 billion when including the ESF contribution, is proving to be a key lever for those Member States worst hit by youth unemployment. There is an indication that the Youth Employment Initiative and the ESF have an important influence on the design of youth employment policy in Member States. For instance, the Youth Employment Initiative and the ESF have supported a shift to demand-based delivery of active labour market policies for young people, with a much stronger focus on individualised assistance. Furthermore, the Commission urges Member States to continue paying special attention to the quality of offers delivered. Over the past three years, Member States have allocated Youth Employment Initiative resources to concrete measures such as traineeships and apprenticeships, first job experiences and support for youth entrepreneurship. As a result, more than 1.3 million young people in Europe have benefited from work and training opportunities. These are strong indications that the Youth Guarantee schemes are on track now, even if much still needs to be done. As regards uptake of the Youth Employment Initiative, the additional pre-financing swiftly decided on by the European co-legislators in 2015 concretely helped to increase the work opportunities for young people on the ground. It is therefore of the utmost importance to use the available European money swiftly. In this context the 2017 draft budget includes a technical adjustment of the cohesion policy national envelopes for 2017-2020 in line with Article 7 of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) regulation. All Member States’ allocations under the investment for growth and jobs goal of cohesion policy for the years 2017-2020 were reviewed and compared to the actual evolution of GDP. The effect of the adjustment is an increase of EUR 4.6 billion, at current prices, in the 2017-2020 ceiling for commitments under economic, social and territorial cohesion – Heading 1b – and concerns Member States particularly affected by the economic slowdown of the past few years. We urge these Member States to use the additional funds for stimulating youth employment as well as for the integration of refugees and promoting investment. I believe that all Member States have to pursue the Youth Guarantee including by directing the necessary national resources to those dedicated actions. As regards a possible extension of the Youth Employment Initiative, the upcoming report on progress with the implementation of the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative and the midterm review of the MFF will provide the opportunity to consider how further to provide financial support for youth employment. Addressing youth unemployment and embarking on reforms in line with the Youth Guarantee remain a key political priority of the European Union. That is what our social market economy is about. As I have said many times before, it is the Commission’s firm intention to steer the European Union more strongly towards social fairness. This means that no one should be left behind, in particular our youth. Europe cannot afford to let the human resources that our young people represent go to waste. Therefore, together with Member States, we should continue our efforts for the implementation of the Youth Guarantee and provide the appropriate financial support.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you for this debate on this oral question. We had sounded the general mobilization of all European states, through the arrowing of the European Social Fund, on youth unemployment: through the youth guarantee, on the one hand, through the youth employment initiative, on the other. These two levers are absolutely essential to succeed in the fight against unemployment and we have deployed all the energy possible, at the level of the European Parliament, to make frontloading, that is to say to load the available funds so that we can start action very quickly; last year, we spent the pre-financing of youth employment initiative projects by 1-30%, even breaking Europe's efficiency records on that day. Being effective is what we are all looking for together. And so, to be effective, we must first measure the effects. This is what we are asking the Commission: what are the effects of the funds and policies we have arrowed into the European Social Fund? The second point: if we want to measure, it is to adjust these policies. In particular, Commissioner, I am asking myself the question of the 25-30 age group. What happened to these young people? Finally, we will have to simplify the measures and guide the evolution of these future projects, because it is the future of young people that is at stake.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the European Commission for being here and for answering the questions in our question. I would like to use my time to express one concept: the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative are essential instruments in the fight against youth unemployment. It is precisely for this reason that we have been promoting this parliamentary initiative, calling for detailed information and a continuous commitment, not just a political one, to carry out two potential programmes.  This situation is confirmed as an emergency but the emergency logic in the management of the problem must be overcome today. The European Parliament is well aware of this, as are the organisations operating on the ground, on a daily basis, including the European Youth Forum, Age Platform, Coface, the European Disability Forum, ISPD, Eurocities, the European Trade Union Confederation. It is precisely these that I have listed that have published a joint declaration this morning on the Youth Guarantee, calling for the immediate extension of the Youth Employment Initiative, continued financial commitment and the development of new methods to improve access for all operators to the funds available. A decisive step forward is called for in verifying that the offers are of quality, the only real path to ensure its long-term sustainability, together with a reduction in the bureaucratic burden for the participating companies.  It is regrettable to read in the preparatory documents for the 2017 budget that the Commission does not plan to include new appropriations for the Youth Employment Initiative for the coming years because of front-loading, but I believe that the mid-term evaluation of the Youth Guarantee, together with what the Commissioner has also said today, will demonstrate that this instrument is essential for making the programmes work.  The European Parliament intends to keep the fight against youth unemployment as a top priority. We will enter shortly, as has already been said in the discussions on the multiannual financial framework, and I am sure that we will be able to do a good job together. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Blue card question. Thank you for agreeing to answer my 'blue card' question. I wanted to ask a very simple thing: do you not think that here there is a lack again, as in your report before, synergy with local and regional authorities and everything they can also do for young people? Because let us not forget that social actions and education often pass through local and regional authorities.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Answer to a blue card question. In fact, I believe that the need for institutional coordination is also taken into account in the wording of the question– of course, it can be done better and better. It is clear that the Youth Employment Initiative, in particular the Youth Guarantee, cannot work without effective work from the European level, going to the Member States and arriving at local and regional authorities. It is an essential thing: I have seen him dealing with the subject a lot, touring the territories and talking to the operators. This is a priority and It seems to me that it is clearly set and the Commission must of course take this into account.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Handel, you were right to say that we are losing an entire generation. And anyone who sees the unemployment figures can only confirm this. You have also said that the impact of the Youth Guarantee programmes is modest. I have looked at the statistics: the effect is unsatisfactory. And then you say: more is urgently needed. We no longer need a formula that does not work. We need a different recipe! We must ask ourselves why youth unemployment is so high in the southern periphery. We must ask ourselves why youth unemployment in Germany has fallen from twelve to seven per cent, why unemployment in Germany has fallen from ten to five per cent. We have to look at that. We need to look at why it went up in the southern periphery. We must finally check this out! We are talking about the fact that we have to take account of the consequences. No, we must look at the causes! The causes are a false exchange rate within the European Monetary Union. That is the reason. That is why our exports are exploding and the export of the southern countries cannot flourish. Why not? Our exports are subsidised. The export of the southern periphery is burdened with taxes. That is what we need to change. Otherwise, I will hear these speeches again in two years' time. I heard it two years ago and I will hear it again in two years' time. This must stop!

name: Marian HARKIN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the Youth Guarantee is a flagship project for the EU and we must deliver on our guarantee. A guarantee is a very strong word. It means we provide a definite assurance, we promise, we pledge to young people that they will receive a quality offer of employment, a traineeship, an apprenticeship, further education within four months of becoming unemployed or of finishing education. When we make that pledge, we must deliver. In order to do that we must have evidence-based policymaking. It is certainly about adequate resources, but equally it is about effective spending. That is why we posed this question to the Commission today. The only information we have to date are the three comments from the Court of Auditors. They talk about having concerns about adequacy of funding, the definition of a good quality offer and how the Commission monitors and reports on the results of the scheme. I listened to the Commissioner here today and perhaps the information is not yet available. Yes, I hear positive comments but, as to the specific question, I am not a lot wiser. One of the questions asked was how we streamline access to the Youth Guarantee, and access is crucial. In this context, I made a complaint to the Commission that young people with disabilities in Ireland are not able to access the Youth Guarantee. I received a reply from the Commission saying that they are satisfied with the Irish Government’s response, which said there were alternative back-to-work supports for young people with disabilities. But the very point of the Youth Guarantee is that it is a guarantee for all young people and there must be no exceptions. In Ireland young people with disabilities are on disability allowance and not on jobseekers’ allowance and so cannot access the Youth Guarantee. We need to streamline our system to ensure that this discrimination is stopped immediately, and we need the support of the Commission in doing this. Member States should not be allowed to slide out of their responsibilities.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank our colleague Thomas Handel for asking this question to the Commission because, in fact, the problem of youth unemployment, which affects one in five Europeans and in Spain one in two young people, needs social policies and, for once, it seemed that the Commission on Austerity and cuts cared about unemployed young people.  However, two years after getting going, the results are dire and uneven. First, the countries that need the most funds to combat youth unemployment are the ones that have the least. Second, employment promotion policies are of little use if thousands and thousands of jobs are being destroyed through anti-social policies and through austerity policies.  In addition, governments such as Spain have shown little or no interest in implementing these measures or have done so in part by creating precarious jobs.  It is now up to the Commission to decide whether to amend the failures that have been committed over the years with this initiative.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, there are two things we can learn from the Brexit referendum that took place last week. The first is that young people, in an overwhelming majority, voted to stay in the European Union. They want to shape the future of Europe together; they want the European Union to solve the political problems of today and to fight for their future. The second thing that we can learn from this referendum is that sadly many young people, especially those who are unemployed, did not go and vote. They feel detached from political processes. For exactly these young people we need to provide answers. The Youth Guarantee is one of the concrete areas where we have to deliver, where we can give answers to those young people who feel detached, who are unemployed and who cannot find apprenticeships or jobs. This is why we will have to fight to make the Youth Guarantee a success, to give young people a voice in the process of decision-making, to create perspectives for those who feel left behind, especially after this Brexit vote. Madam Commissioner, young people did not let us down in the vote last week. I beg you, do not let young people down, not now.

name: Laura AGEA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President of the Commission, I feel like I have déjà vu. We are still here talking about the Youth Guarantee, we are here once again calling for this measure to combat the effects of unemployment to be implemented; we are even calling for it to be stabilised and for it to become a systemic measure to help unemployment. Unfortunately, this is not the way. This is not the way to go because we know full well that, in view of the economic commitment allocated to this conflict measure, the results are extremely disappointing. I bring the experience of my country that has completely failed this implementation. We come from the same country, Mr Benifei, but we probably talk to different people. I will let you have the e-mails of many young people who write to me that, one year into the Young Guarantee path, they have not yet been paid and ask me why and if it is normal. No, it's not normal!  They ask me whether it is normal simply to receive the proposal to take a training course or an internship, we are not even talking about apprenticeship, which would already be something closer to the world of work.  So we must learn to face reality and to realise that certain instruments do not work if Europe pours money into rain and does not control it and if it does not tackle the problem of unemployment effectively and try to solve it structurally. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Blue card question. The question raised by Mrs Agea is very correct. We have huge implementation issues. In fact, the question went in this direction. But at least my assessment – and I wanted to ask my colleague about this – is that we must move forward in improving and monitoring expenditure, in making sure that there is no waste. Previously, there was talk of monitoring local authorities as well and of cooperating with the regions. I believe that interrupting a project is a mistake: for many, however, the Youth Guarantee was a way to find a chance.

name: Laura AGEA
text: Answer to a blue card question. Mr Benifei, we must not play with words: stop, continue... That is not the order of the problems. It is that if we do not monitor how local authorities manage and use this tool, we are not going anywhere. Less than a year ago, I called on Commissioner Thyssen to manage the Youth Guarantee in the province of Terni. She herself responded by saying: 'We are monitoring because what you are telling us, and therefore of not exactly transparent management, is for real and so we are moving to verify'. Do it yourself.

name: Anne SANDER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, three years after the launch of the Youth Guarantee, about one in five young people is still unemployed. So we need to look at the effectiveness of our policy and take stock. Brexit has also cast a harsh light on the dysfunctions of the European Union, but I would say especially about those in the Member States. In any case, they challenge us even more. So I have a number of questions, Commissioner. Firstly, what is the European Commission doing to simplify and make funding for youth employment accessible to as many people as possible? In France, due to the complexity of the procedures, the youth employment initiative often benefits the same structures without hitting new targets. Second, if the youth employment initiative is extended after 2017, how can we benefit those who are in the blind spot of our public policy? I am thinking, in particular, of young people from rural areas and the least qualified young people. Thirdly, despite the Erasmus programme, there are still few young apprentices crossing borders and I would say that cross-border apprenticeship projects, such as those we have in the Upper Rhine, are too rare. So what is Europe doing to develop this type of project? (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. "You said at the beginning of your speech that we should draw conclusions. And I have heard that you have only drawn conclusions concerning the European Union as an institution. At the same time, would you be willing to draw a conclusion that applies to the Member States? For example, the Hungarian government has taken the limit of compulsory education from 18 to 16. Unemployment among young people has therefore risen mercilessly. Do you think this is the Fault of the European Union?

name: Anne SANDER
text: "blue card" answer. "No, I agree with you, Mr MEP, there is a real responsibility of the Member States. That is what I said when I talked about the dysfunctions of the European Union, but above all about the dysfunctions in the Member States. In my country, for example, in France, there are also important improvements that should allow projects to reach a much wider audience, and to really help young people in difficulty, which is not always the case today.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Thank you very much for an exciting debate. When you have listened to it for a while, you might think that the youth unemployment thing is for southern Italy. I can now say that even in a reasonably rich and undamaged country such as Sweden, we have major problems with youth unemployment.  I do not think that there should be those simplest explanations, and I think it is very important that we continue and work on this kind of programme that we have in order to give a chance for young people to enter the labour market. We have asked the Commissioner questions on several occasions: is this really working? Is it worth continuing to bet? Does it cost too much, does it give too little? Each time we get quite optimistic answers. Now Madame Thyssen said it's a key. Let us hope that it is a key and let us be persistent in defending and replenishing this money for as long as possible, because it will turn around.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We are talking today about the European Youth Guarantee. The Youth Guarantee means that Member States should provide a job, training place or traineeship for a young person who has been unemployed for more than four months, and a high-quality one. To this end, the EU will provide almost €13 billion between 2014 and 2020. However, not even the Court of Auditors knows whether such a permanent job has ever been created, and the German Trade Union Confederation also considers this Youth Guarantee to be a zero number. I fear that many here have not yet got the message of Brexit and will continue to hold on to such abstruse projects as a Europe-wide, state-imposed employment policy. Instead of promoting ever-new socialist labour market projects in the GDR, we should relieve the small and medium-sized enterprises of the planned billions of euros so that they can create jobs. The lesson of Brexit must be: less EU, less euro, more subsidiarity – also and above all for the labour market.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Madam President, young and unemployed means a young person who does not have an income, therefore no perspective of buying a house, to start a family, no prospect of investing in their further education to improve their chances for the future. This is why youth unemployment is so important. It is good that we are discussing it today. Madam Commissioner, two concrete proposals from my side and two concrete questions. Firstly, there are Member States of the Union in which youth unemployment is below 10% and then there are Member States in which it is above 30-40%. Therefore, I truly believe that we have to do more to improve the exchange of best practices between the Member States of the Union in order to give the young people of Europe the opportunity to be part of the best programmes which exist in Europe, be it in their Member State or in another Member State. Therefore, also the question: what is the Commission doing in order to improve the exchange of best practices amongst the Member States of the Union? Secondly, we of course have to make sure that this programme generates stable and well-paid jobs. That is why we should in our evaluation go beyond just the quantitative evaluation of these projects –how many jobs were created – but really make sure that these jobs are stable and well paid. My two questions to you are: when will the Commission come up with the evaluation of this programme? Why has it been delayed? Secondly, what is the Commission doing to inform eligible young people of these opportunities?

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: – The Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative are steps in the right direction for those millions of young people who are at home because of a lack of employment.  It is a crisis that these young people have not caused, but which often leads to a lost generation, the word has been here before. The EU, as the Commissioner has just said, is slowly emerging from the crisis, but Brexit is creating new uncertainty about our economic prospects. So it is indeed time that we put pressure on real investment and growth and jobs through this debate, so that we can offer a perspective to countries that are still deeply in debt. Because it is young people in Spain, in several Eastern European countries and, above all, in Greece, who deserve our support. So there must be continued investment in the youth guarantee. But I ask you, Commissioner, should we not invest more in growth and jobs in Europe in general?

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I am pleased to hear that we are seeing greater implementation of these programmes at Member State level. But what is essential to be done is a qualitative analysis so that we know what the results of these programmes are at European level. We cannot agree with situations where Member States are masking unemployment data by becoming more than estranged in traineeships and training and by making sure that our young people do not then have an effective insertion in the quality labour market and therefore this control is absolutely essential. And so, Commissioner, we need to do a very careful monitoring and evaluation that cannot - and I repeat - go through only a quantitative but also qualitative and individualised assessment to the fullest, so that we can combat the abuses of companies that are becoming traineeship specialists and which make our young people eternally dependent on these mechanisms. On the other hand, when we talk about the extension of the initiative - which I support, and I will tell you my position, Commissioner - we must also make sure that there is indeed a differentiation across Europe in the way these programmes are implemented. Unemployment in my region, for example in the Azores, is one of the highest in Europe and we cannot, we cannot have the same answers in the Azores that we offer, for example, to a region in Germany, which has the lowest unemployment rates. We need to ensure that differentiation.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I was very surprised by your complacent analysis of the implementation of the Youth Guarantee, because just a month ago in your assessment of national country reform programmes I said the exact opposite. It said verbatim that the national Youth Guarantee system, in reference to Spain, was not yet delivering the expected results and the registration ratio remained very low. And it is true, in Spain we have more than one million unemployed young people and the Youth Guarantee has barely reached 60,000 young people in Spain. What is the Youth Guarantee? It is a promise we made from the European institutions to young people that in a period of four months we would offer them a job offer or a formative period. And we have failed to do so, because the Youth Guarantee is not only that sufficient funding is needed, which we don't have, the 6 billion euros have shown that they are not, but it is also how that $6 billion is applied or spent. We believe and are advocates of the program, but we need to change it from top to bottom. We need the European Commission to force Member States to meet minimum requirements, to comply with guidelines, to create quality employment and to co-finance, in order precisely to fulfil the promise we have solemnly made to them from this European Parliament.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – The Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative are certainly two very useful measures implemented by the European Union, and they can help a generation that today has the greatest employment difficulties, that is, young people. However, we must also be aware that there is a great deal of depend on the Member States for the employment of young people, and they must, through the reform of the education system, the integration of education, research and also the economy, create the conditions in which these jobs will then be created. I therefore fully support this direction in order to do a detailed analysis of how these funds are being used, but at the same time it also sees good practices and then, from country to country, specifically determine which and how this measure will be most effective in each country. We do not need to talk only about the responsibility of the European Union, but we must also talk to a large extent about the responsibility of the Member States, which often deny at this level.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to say to you, as concluded by my colleague Sergio Gutierrez, that I was surprised by your gratrelevance about how this programme is working in the various countries, especially mine, in Spain. You have said that some Member States show great improvement and this initiative is working. This initiative is very important, this programme is very important, but it is not working, Commissioner. And the data there are, in Spain, with that million unemployed young people, 49.6%, 30 points above average. It's really alarming. Moreover, the move taken by the Spanish Government is absolutely ineffective and wrong. The bonus of 300 euros to entrepreneurs for social security contribution is absolutely useless, it is already demonstrated in other programs. Therefore, Commissioner, on behalf of my group, on behalf of the unemployed young Spaniards, this programme must be changed so that it has a future.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the European Union is full of armies of the poor and unemployed. There are already over 4.2 million unemployed young people. Unemployment among 21 million Europeans, as well as youth unemployment, is due to mercelian austerity and violent fiscal adjustment. Measures to reduce youth unemployment, such as the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative, will therefore not bear fruit, as long as the Member States stick to the Schäuble directives, for a tough austerity policy. So, Commissioner Thyssen, although you, as a Commission, apply the Schäuble doctrine, Schäuble himself finally empties you, criticises you further and gives you a red card, trying to pin on you the failures of his own economic policy, which has turned the European South, and especially In Greece, into an area of mass unemployment. Moreover, Mrs Thyssen, the sum of EUR 6.2 billion is crumbs, so that they can at least ease the adverse social consequences of youth unemployment.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to encourage the Commission to conclude the youth guarantee assessments realistically, independently and objectively in order to achieve the best result of a fundamental programme for the future of many young people and the institutional prestige of the Union when it needs it most.  It is necessary to ensure that it is the institutions competent in active employment policies that assume the management of funds. In Spain, competition is regional, for example in the Basque Country, and the distribution is totally incongruous. In addition, the Spanish Government has created a specific register for so-called ninis so complex and opaque that some of the funds that should have financed active employment programmes have been devoted to creating, managing and disseminating it, clearly doubling existing services and making up, by the way, the real impact of unemployment.  I would like to ask you, Commissioner, whether the Commission is aware of these problems and whether you are considering any strategy to be able to correct them. I'd like you to answer me.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Madam President, the dysfunction in the implementation of the Youth Guarantee and Youth Employment Initiative programmes guarantees that these programmes will fail. name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: member of the Commission. – We read from the figures, if we look at the evolution of youth unemployment statistics, that this trend is positive. In the past year – I count from The Month of May this year compared to The Month of May of last year – there have been 503 000 fewer young people out of work. That is the lowest unemployment rate for young people since March 2009. That is why I believe that something positive can be said. But does that mean that I'm satisfied, that I think we're there and that everything goes perfectly? Far from it! Because if we look at the rate of youth unemployment today, we see that this is still 18.6%, although two full percentage points better than last year, but 18.6% of young unemployed, with 4 197 000 young people looking for work behind it. That is 4 197 000 too many, so we must continue our policy. What I am not very positive about is the fact that the budgets we have with our funds are being taken up slowly. Absorption is slow. There are all sorts of reasons for this that we hear from the Member States. They were still running the previous programs, the capacity was lacking. We have increased pre-financing, which has helped something. In the end, however, the uptake of the amounts was too slow. We're not really happy about that.  But what does that mean? That we need to continue to work on all fronts that can create more jobs for young people, and that includes macroeconomic policies to ensure that there is more growth and jobs. In this context, we have launched our European Investment Fund, and this is also proving to be paying off. Because investments have already been agreed for more than EUR 100 billion, and that is something. Having the right macroeconomic policies is one thing, but we also need to continue to work on social policy. That is a second priority. We continue to do this by passing on the youth guarantee. It is about structural reforms that are needed to get the young people involved, to have them registered, to be able to deal with them and to make them an offer that helps them get back on the path that can lead to a job. We need to evaluate that now. The Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative, the special fund to evaluate the youth guarantee. We are not too late for that. Some of you suggest, "Why too late? I'd like an answer." That evaluation will come on time! Member States were asked to provide us with the data by the end of May at the latest. That data has been more or less collected or it is on its way. They must now be processed and a report will be drawn up on that basis and we will be able to present that report to you in the course of autumn. If you invite me to do so, I will be happy to come here and explain it. That report should give us the right basis to see how we go. If we continue with the same thing, something needs to be changed, under what conditions can we do that: that has to be agreed.  An important question will also be: do we want to once again devote specific funds to supporting the Youth Guarantee, to combating youth unemployment? That is where, of course, we have to take into account the MFK, the multianne financial framework, and we cannot simply take the money out of the air. You know that the money comes from the Member States.  What we have already done in the technical adjustment, and with it, we know that we are coming to a budget of EUR 4.6 billion, which will ultimately have to be divided on several issues, but one of the priorities that the Commission will propose is that this amount be spent on combating youth unemployment. For the rest, we will have to wait until we have produced that report and, as I said, I am happy to come back to you for that.  But don't say, even outside this Chamber, that the Commissioner was so happy, because there is still 18% youth unemployment. I'm happy we're moving forward. We are seeing progress from month to month and we are talking about large numbers of young people who end up in the labour market and find a job. Let us be satisfied with that for five minutes. But being satisfied doesn't mean that we're sitting with our hands in our laps, that we think we've achieved our goal. I've called you the numbers, far from it. We will all have to work very hard together to give young people better opportunities, and you can count on the Commission for that.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Since April 2013, EU Member States have implemented this youth guarantee and the youth employment initiative as miracle cures for the problem of youth employment. However, if I take stock of the employment of young people in my country and especially the least educated and those furthest from the job market, I find that one in five young people is still unemployed in Europe (25% in France and more than 50% in Greece!). As such, Brexit has cast a harsh light on the dysfunctions of the European Union but also on those in the Member States. The problems remain unresolved. The complexity of the procedures and the European bureaucracy often do not allow us to reach new targets.  On the other hand, rural youth and the least skilled young people are still too far from the labour market despite yet another scheme. Finally, the problem of youth employment is primarily a matter of national logic: reforms of education systems but also the promotion of learning, which too often remains poorly perceived in some countries such as my own, France.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – It is good to see that youth unemployment figures have fallen in both the EU-28 and the Eurozone. But this is no time to welcome or let your guard down because there are still more than 4 million young people out of work in Europe and because many of the jobs that have been created are precarious jobs with unworthy wages. Now it's time to do a thorough analysis of the implementation of the youth guarantee. My country, for example, has done so slowly, insufficiently and irresponsiblely. Slow because it took more than a year and a half to get it up and running. Insufficient because, in February 2015, only 60,000 young people had found a job and irresponsible because the system is primarily being used to give bonuses to businesses. That is why I believe that the time has come to commit to a true European Youth Guarantee, with more funds and a minimum framework to ensure the quality of job offers, the dignity of the scholarships received and the excellence of the education received.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. – 'Youth Guarantee' should promote the integration of young people into the world of work, but youth unemployment rates in different Regions of Europe remain dramatically high. For many, it is seen as a failure to promote active and effective policies in the labour market. Many doubts continue to remain about the quality of the offer, the ability of the program, as implemented, to give guarantees of growth and strengthening the employability of the person and the consolidation of his skills. There is no shortage of cases of recourse to this instrument in ways aimed at employing cheap labour without training intentions. Furthermore, I myself have received several reports that payments to trainees, many of whom have already completed their traineeships, do not occur or are unacceptable delays in disbursement, creating further inconvenience for thousands of young people who are experiencing the tragedy of unemployment on their own skin.

text: in writing. – Dear Mr President, although only introduced 3 years ago, the Youth Employment Initiative and the Youth Guarantee schemes have shown good results in terms of providing support for young people as they move from the education system to the labour market. However, the level of unemployed young people in the EU remains too high, reaching 25% in places, and the trend towards using traineeships as an alternative means of low-paid exploitation continues. I believe that more European funding is needed to support initiatives to combat youth unemployment and additional programmes aimed at finding solutions to reduce unemployment among the older age segment: 25-35 years. In addition, I believe that we also need programmes to encourage the development of skills in the 21st century while young people are in the secondary education system and to ensure better regulation of traineeship opportunities and practical training.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. – We must not postpone an assessment of the Youth Guarantee indefinitely, because the facts are already on the table. We have policies that do not work, such as direct subsidy to recruitment, which cannot be the center of the implementation of the youth guarantee in many countries. We have administrations that lack the resources and political will to guide young people towards employment or training, so additional means and clear criteria are needed for workers to define their career and training itineraries. And we need the participation of trade unions to ensure that the rights of young workers are respected and we start from a global view of their employment. These issues must be resolved for the extension of the Youth Guarantee which, I recall, is chronically underfunded. Between 21 billion and 48 billion per year are needed to cover all potential beneficiaries, focused on those countries and regions with the highest youth unemployment. And I would add: together with training and youth recruitment policies, we must address the macroeconomic determinants of the high unemployment rate. It is inescapable to address the distribution of work and a real convergence of production models.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: In writing. I have approved the report unanimously adopted by the Committee on Budgetary Control, which calls on Parliament to postpone its decision on discharge to the Secretary General of the Council on the implementation of the European Council and Council budget for the 2014 financial year. This is the result of a lack of transparency by the Council with regard to the funds entrusted to it. Parliament therefore asks the Council to submit its annual report of activities including a detailed overview of all the human resources available to the two institutions, broken down by category, rank, gender, nationality and vocational training. The report also highlights the worrying lack of transparency in the legislative process, negotiations, member states' positions and meetings. It calls on the Commission to publish relevant documents and to establish a clear reporting system that allows the public to follow legislative procedures in an open and transparent manner.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – Young people all over Europe have very high expectations of us. We are expected to overcome differences in order to work in the interests of the younger generation.  The Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative are mechanisms by which direct action can be taken to support young Europeans. Unfortunately, the results show that only certain states have implemented these projects.  In my country, Romania, although the former Social Democratic government has implemented a pilot project on the youth guarantee and developed a coherent strategy in this area, the current technocratic government has forgotten about young people, despite numerous calls from civil society. That is why I want to continue these projects and expand them by supplementing budgets and integrating the European Youth Plan proposed by the Party of European Socialists.  Thus, we need an extensive strategy that vertically includes support for every stage of the young person's life, from schooling and skills development, to finding a job and starting a family, and horizontally combating inequalities, reintegrating excluded young people and providing equal opportunities for young people.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. – Combating youth unemployment is one of the most significant challenges in the European Union. It is about promoting social cohesion seeking to ensure a safe professional path and the consequent development of a life project for the new generations. Alongside unemployment, there is another problem that also concerns young people and should deserve our greatest attention: precariousness, low-paid intermittent work with low or no guarantees of staying in the future. Without secure employment there is no young emancipation and without it it becomes difficult to secure a roadmap for sustainable economic and social development. The program "Jovem Guarantee", in good time started, was one of the paths pursued. It essentially focuses on the transition between the formative path and the contact with the labour market. It is, of course, not critical or completely fit for needs. As has been said both in this Parliament and in other forums, some less achieved points need to be improved. It is therefore important to assess in depth the results recorded so far and to do so by seeking to take into account the real impact of this programme on the effective generation of employment. Europe can do better in tackling this scourge.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: Writing. – The Youth Guarantee programme was one of the European responses to the disappointing labour market situation after the economic crisis, to which the Member States are committed. At the same time, the instrument can be well suited to what many have said many times in recent years: it can bring the EU closer to citizens and especially to young people. This is also important because all Member States have a low level of public interest in young people, and the European Union often appears only in a negative context, which is why the European project has lost much of its popularity. This should also be taken into attention in the implementation of the programme: it is a European-initiative measure that directly affects hundreds of thousands of young people. Perhaps it also applies here that by simplifying funding and better communication, it is possible to bring the EU closer to its citizens and to show tangible results in addressing the negative effects of the economic crisis.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. – The Youth Guarantee programme was a new approach to tackling youth unemployment, which we approved with a view to ensuring youth employment in the long term. However, I wonder whether the Member States are really implementing the measures under the programme as they should and whether the programme is achieving its purpose. In Slovenia, a survey has recently been carried out among young people and the results of the latter are worrying. Young people are very critical of the implementation of the programme, with less than 10% of young people actually employed after the programme expired. They also believe that some courses are useless, inadequate and unsuitable for individuals. I am not familiar with the surveys in other Member States. But what can we learn from this? There is an urgent need to increase the participation of all stakeholders and to strengthen the oversight of the implementation of the programmes. I also believe that, as a complement to the programme, the Youth Guarantee is essential to implement reforms and improve education and training systems.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. – Recently, the employment rate among young people has improved in the EU, with around 4.4 million unemployed among under-25s in February 2016, while until recently around 5 million were still unemployed. However, it is difficult to assess whether the improvement is linked to the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative, or whether it stems from other circumstances. For example, the EU Court of Auditors' special report on youth employment measures estimates that the use of funds was not sufficiently focused on results. These two mechanisms were proposed at a time when the youth unemployment rate in the EU was extremely high and there was no indication that it was going to start to fall. As rapporteur for the EES Group for Legislative Opinion, I participated in last year's increase in pre-financing under the Yei Initiative. This represented around €1 billion for half a million young people in 20 EU countries. Last year, however, I pointed out the importance of the efficient use of resources. The European Commission should monitor spending so that money really benefits end-users, unemployed young people, not bureaucrats and intermediaries. Member States must demonstrate that the activities financed by the two mentioned mechanisms have actually led to higher employment among young people.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the report by Dario Tamburrano on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, debate on the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the definition of energy efficiency labelling and repealing Directive 2010/30/EU (COM (2015)0341 - C8-0189/2015 - 2015/0149(COD)) (A8-0213/2016).

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the energy label is a successful European story, which began more than twenty years ago and has been copied by everyone in the world. It is the passport recognized by all, which guarantees many products that are on the market and that enter the homes of 500 million citizens, to inform about the performance related to energy efficiency and other fundamental characteristics. Together with ecodesign, the energy label has allowed European citizens in a few years to be able to buy washing machines, refrigerators, ovens, light bulbs and boilers that are increasingly efficient over time, thus saving huge amounts of energy, harmful emissions and money, thus reducing diseases, environmental damage and, no less importantly, partially reducing the political dependence of our continent.  For some years now, however, the label's information capacity has lost its efficiency, it has to be said. Consumers are confused by too many different scales. The advent of classes with so-called "+" has made the difference between the steps less clear and therefore between products, in terms of energy consumption, price and more. So, quite rightly, the time has come to renew this passport, making it more effective, taking advantage of the advances in information technology, which are fundamental to representing and communicating the current and future market. In drawing up the draft report that I had the honour of conducting, I took on board the objectives of the original proposal with the aim of putting the '+' in order as soon as possible, digitising information and strengthening market surveillance. In recent months I have heard the voices of consumers, industries, small and medium-sized enterprises, supervisory authorities, shopkeepers, standardisation authorities, non-governmental organisations and citizens registered with various political actors. I have proposed a deliberately broad and complex report, with the aim of decisively strengthening the confidence of European citizens following the scandals in the automotive sector, which threaten, let us remember, the credibility of all our regulatory efforts.  I hope I have contributed to the proposal for a modern label, let us call it 2.0, in step with the times, capable of being not only a sticker, but also a gateway to a product database, which can be used by everyone, with more information, comparable and finally described in their own language. The negotiating work has made it possible to arrive at a vote in committee with a solid text, which I believe is shared and balanced, which was then unanimously approved in the ITRE Committee and which will, I hope, arrive in this House on Wednesday for confirmation with the same enthusiasm.  Among the various improvements found in the text, I would like to highlight, in particular, Parliament's desire to strengthen the mechanism for setting the standards underlying the allocation of efficiency classes; more transparency and more control and full consideration of the conditions of real use of the products; tests and inspections should be more frequent and information on the results shared with all European supervisors. We have agreed to set up a database divided into two sections, one public and one with access reserved for the competent authorities; a database that will enter into force as soon as possible and will also be accessible through a quercode present on the label and that will allow to evaluate and compare the data and characteristics entered by the manufacturers. We have identified an automatic mechanism to eliminate the "+" from the labels and therefore the A+, A++, A+++ classes in a certain and short time, with one exception represented by the group of boilers that, due to their peculiar characteristics and market dynamics, need a wider time.  We have also identified a general rule for so-called 'heating' according to the employment of the upper classes. A reassignment mechanism will be triggered... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Tamburrano, and his colleagues for the work that has been done on this very important file. One of the underpinning principles of the European Union is to empower consumers and citizens and allow them to drive the clean energy transition that Europe needs. It was in that spirit that, in July 2015, the Commission made a proposal to update the legal framework for the energy-efficiency labelling of products, and since its introduction 20 years ago, energy labelling has ensured that consumers are able to make more informed choices that will help them to save energy and money. More than 85% of us actually check the energy label before buying a new fridge or a new washing machine. Per year, energy-labelling and eco-design policies taken together represent a savings potential for consumers of up to EUR 465 million and can bring around EUR 55 billion in extra revenue for business, which goes to show that this is as much about energy security as it is about sustainability or competitiveness. The good news is that the labelling has accelerated the development of ever-more efficient products, and that should be applauded. Ironically, it also means that the label has increasingly become a victim of its own success. Today’s energy labelling needs updating: many models are in the highest classes and thereby no longer provide differentiation for consumers. As the rapporteur said, with the addition of A+, A++ and A+++ classes, the label scale became less efficient in persuading consumers to buy more efficient products. So these pluses have actually become minuses for consumers. Following extensive consultation, and responding to consumer requests, the Commission therefore proposed returning to the original A-to-G energy label scale and periodically rescaling it. Ultimately, this is about providing clear information for consumers to ensure that they are equipped to make the most informed and efficient choices. Today, consumers want to know about the energy efficiency of appliances as much as they want to know about the calories in food, and we need to make it as simple as that. That is why we very much welcome the support of the rapporteur and the European Parliament, which has allowed us to make significant progress on this important proposal.  There are lots of interesting ideas in the report, including on rescaling. However, there are two changes suggested in the report that I must flag because, in our view, they are likely to undermine the success of the planned product database and we must make sure that we know the impact of these changes. The provision to allow manufacturers to keep compliance information on their own service, while being centrally accessible for market surveillance authorities, will be technically very challenging and costly and we have profound concerns over its workability. The report also suggests giving less time to the Commission to establish the database: one year instead of two. This timing is not realistic. Rushing the establishment of the database could lead to a bad-quality database and we do not want that. The deadline could also turn out to be one that we cannot meet, and that should be avoided. So I look forward to working with this House and with the Council to ensure that rescaling and the product database can be implemented in practice without a high administrative burden. Ultimately, the new label has to work for consumers. They are the ones who drive the change in the way we consume energy and we must give them the tools to do so.

name: Herbert REUL
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has First of all a thank you for the good cooperation, it was damn exhausting. Secondly, the label is a success story – as all colleagues have said. After a long period of work, we have reached a compromise. I would like to say now that if this compromise is changed very much by means of votes on Wednesday, then we will no longer be able to support this compromise, then it will no longer be ours. So I think we should consider whether we are going to revisit the matter with amendments at all, or whether we are not leaving what we have achieved in committee, with advantages and disadvantages, simply now. I also have some major concerns, and I will also raise them. There are two big ones. The first of our group goes against the database. It is difficult to understand, at a time when everyone is supposed to focus on the big things and the governments of the Member States, in cooperation on really central issues, refuse to set up central European databases here. I don't understand that at the back and in the front. This audit report, which is to enter these databases, is approximately the size of a file folder. A normal manufacturer has 25 000 products on the market, so it has to add a quantity of 25 000 file folders to online databases. It's not particularly funny. The costs will also be higher. The Commission says EUR 1.5 million, and we expect that there will be much more – from people who need to work on it. And the question of whether the purpose is given is also questionable, because the market surveillance authorities have expressed no interest at all and do not want it at all. Then there is data protection, because in the end everyone knows that we have very careful, sensitive data here that does not have to be accessible to others. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Martina WERNER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would also like to begin by thanking the rapporteur and my fellow Members – as Mr Roll has just mentioned – for the really good, hard cooperation. Energy efficiency is a key building block of the Energy Union, because by further increasing the efficient use of energy, we can conserve and save resources. Here I think there is also great potential that can help us to achieve our common goals for climate protection. In addition, the most efficient use of energy also strengthens our independence from third countries and, above all, protects the wallets of everyone, consumers and entrepreneurs. The energy label is a success. The designation of energy efficiency classes has now also made it possible for consumers to compare products and, above all, to make an informed purchasing decision. This has contributed significantly to the fact that the products covered by the energy label have been continuously developed and are now significantly more efficient than before. A good energy efficiency class is a crucial buying argument, and it is therefore also in the interests of industry to use this as a competitive advantage. The success has resulted in many electrical appliances falling into the best energy efficiency class today and is actually the worst efficiency class for some A+ products. This confusion is leading to increasing confusion among consumers. It is really high time that we provided clarity when buying electrical appliances and that the label finally became consumer-friendly again. That is why I am also proud that together we have managed to find a really good, strong compromise on the essential points. Firstly, the return to a uniform efficiency class from A to G across all product groups will provide clarity and will once again help consumers to compare products at a glance and to be able to decide at once how efficient this is. Secondly, it is good that the most common household appliances should be labelled within 21 months and that other product groups, with the exception of recently scaled heaters, should be added within five years at the latest. Thirdly, by setting up a database with a closed platform for the competent authorities – and this is the difference between a publicly available information page for consumers – market surveillance in the Member States will be strengthened. And, as I have heard, this is also supported by the Member States. At one point or another, from our point of view, from a social democratic point of view, there are still a few points that we could well regulate in the best possible way: we believe that a central database is appropriate, and as Social Democrats we support the member states being able to incentivise low-income consumers. We have achieved a great deal with the compromises that have been reached. That is why I also ask that we take the decisions by a large majority and that we also give the rapporteur responsibility for the trialogue.

name: Ashley FOX
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, my group welcomes this report on energy labelling. The current system confuses consumers and I am pleased that the A+, A++ and A+++ categories are being scrapped and we are reverting back to the A to G scale. We are also pleased to see a five-year timescale to achieve this transition. This is a reasonable period for both producers and consumers. We do have some reservations about the creation of a product database. We are, though, satisfied that the proposed tax clarifies the requirements on producers which were lacking in the Commission proposal. This database has the potential to be a useful market surveillance tool, but we do not want it to become too great a burden on industry. We are also satisfied that this report requires the Commission to consider a ten-year timescale when deciding on future energy labels. Rescaling labels will impose a cost on industry and it is right that both producers and consumers are provided with certainty over this time period. Overall, we believe this legislation will benefit consumers without increasing costs. We believe the existing directive is working well and would caution against some of the amendments made by other groups that would add much unnecessary prescription without benefiting consumers. This would threaten smaller companies and stifle innovation. Overall this is a good report and my group will vote in favour on Wednesday. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. You have given a lengthy account of the benefits of this new system, primarily from the point of view of consumers and from the point of view of consumers, and leave it to consumers to judge the products in particular. But do you really think that the players in this industry deserve protection rather than be encouraged in some way?

name: Ashley FOX
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, Mr President, I do think these labels will benefit consumers because at the moment we have certain product types where everything is either an A+++, A++ or A+ so the least efficient products have an A+ and consumers think they are buying a good product when it is actually the least effective. And I do accept that any legislation does impose a burden on producers and industry and that results in higher prices to consumers, but my judgment is this proposal gets the balance right.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – The reform of this energy label must serve me different purposes. Firstly, it must ensure that the producer is encouraged to innovate and bring more energy-efficient appliances to market. Secondly, we want better, more efficient control of the market. This can be done through better cooperation and information exchange by the member states' control agencies.  Finally, it must also ensure that consumers buy more energy-efficient appliances. This reduces consumption and reduces energy bills. For me, it is also essential that we pursue these goals in a way that is as simple as possible for the consumer, the producer and the sellers. We have to take into account our small, local dealers and our SMEs. We must not impose unnecessary costs or burdens on them.
