I think that with the outcome of the ITRE vote, we have found a very good compromise between the positions of the different groups and between the interests of the various steakholders involved. I think we have taken an ambitious approach. One that makes it clear to everyone what can and can't. We are still in the wake of the Volkswagen scandal, which is why it is more important than ever that we ensure that consumers regain confidence in the labels they see. And I want to be very clear about that. For me, a refrigerator that consumes too much electricity is as bad as a car that consumes too much diesel. In both cases, you as a consumer are misled, it is bad for the environment and you will feel that in your wallet, at the petrol pump or at the energy bill.  I look forward to the negotiations with the Member States and will defend this ambitious approach with them.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr President-in-Office of the Council. Tamburrano, for the very good work he has done. Our group, the GUE, has argued from the outset that it is important to ensure an energy labelling system that is understandable to consumers, but which also includes all the necessary information. We therefore welcome the proposals contained in the report to delete misleading symbols and move to a simpler, uniform labelling system from A to G. That is why we have tabled an amendment calling for this system to be applied immediately and to all products without exception.  Equally important is the proposal put forward in the report to create a new digital database for products, to which consumers will have free access. However, we believe that it is very important that this database provides more information on products, but also on consumer rights, in order to enhance transparency and thus put a stop to profiteering and misleading consumers by large companies. However, in order to be able to move forward with all this, it is important that we all give the rapporteur a vote of confidence so that he can start negotiations with the Council and the Commission immediately.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Indeed, there is a very important file being debated here in Parliament, and it is very important that consumers are properly informed about the energy consumption data of the products they buy. However, the report that we finally adopted in the ITRE Committee does not contain much of The Reporter Tamburrano's original proposal. And in order to provide consumers with the right information, it is necessary to return elements that have been removed on the fly. It is inevitable that the reporter will be given an appropriate mandate to continue negotiations with the Commission and the Council. It is inevitable that the new single energy labelling from A to G should cover all product groups by 2023 at the latest, not just sometime in 2030. In order to provide information on how much energy they will consume during their operation, we need a central database and, finally, a single single label per product group.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. This report on a new energy efficiency labelling of household appliances is primarily in the interests of consumers. The innovations are label 2.0 – as the rapporteur has called it, and I would also like to thank very much – and the database, which, as we have already heard today, is not without controversy and which is not without controversy on the part of the national market observation authorities, whose work it is supposed to facilitate. The aim is to increase the efficiency of energy efficiency labelling by making it easier to scale, i.e. to return to well-known and proven scale Labels A to G for energy-efficient products, including a process for rescaling the existing labels A+++ plus to D. The energy label is a success story – we have already heard it today: 85% of European consumers rely on this label when making purchase decisions, and it is also a driving force in the industry for innovative developments: EUR 450 million has been saved by the labels. However, in order to make it easier for consumers to compare products, there will only be a uniform A to G energy label in the future. The consumer should buy the most efficient product. This should lead to a reduction in energy consumption and energy costs. Particularly important: The actual power consumption should be indicated on the label, measured under real conditions and not under laboratory conditions. The rapporteur has also found a good middle ground for future rescaling: rescaling is automatically triggered when 25% of the products sold in a category fall into the top efficiency class A or 50% in classes A and B. My aim was to save trade as much as possible – little extra effort. That has been achieved.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, my thanks to the rapporteur. I think it is important when you discuss energy efficiency labelling that the whole idea is not to get things right. The whole idea is to make things better and better, and that is why it is so important to have clear labelling that is easy to understand because that will empower consumers to always make a better choice and support industry which wants to develop better technologies. And I think this is important not only for this discussion but for a lot of other discussions about energy use and energy efficiency. Every new generation, whatever machinery it is, is better than the last. And those who think we can do better by freezing development are also fundamentally wrong. That is a very clear sign from this discussion about energy labelling. And that is why I also think it is important not to believe here in bureaucracy too much, not to believe that we can achieve this by regulations. This is business-driven not database-driven, and if the database is not simple, easy, non-bureaucratic, it will hinder, it will freeze the development. And that is why I gave the support to the compromises but I also would like to underline that this must be open for business-driven technology and business-driven variation and dialogue with consumers.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the fight against climate change and energy security also go through the free and conscious choice of consumers who, preferring solutions, that is to say, in this case, energy-efficient appliances and devices, allow energy savings that in Europe in 2020 will reach 175 million tonnes of oil equivalent, equal to the entire primary energy needs in Italy over the course of a year.  Focusing, therefore, on the efficiency of household appliances is a common sense choice, in the interests of those who will have to use these appliances at home, but it also gives continuity and coherence to European policies on the subject of energy and climate, of which this legislation has made a major element.  The text that has been dismissed – and I too would like to thank Mr Tamburrano for the excellent work he has done – is very much to be welcomed. Starting from the state of technological progress and consider and exempt some typical features of the supply chain, for example overheating, updates and simplifies the pictographic scale, making it less equivocal, clearer and more readable.  I hope that in the negotiations with the Council we will be able to keep a few points still.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, this regulation, as has already been said, on energy efficiency labelling is undoubtedly key in providing citizens and consumers with the best information, the best knowledge of the impact that existing products on the market can have on the energy bill, on the electricity bill, and, in turn, it is a regulation which will contribute , without a doubt, to the emission reduction target. It is necessary to readjust the labelling in view of the overpopulation between the most efficient classes of certain products, subtracting value at the very scale and the information it provides to the citizen. The proposal is also sensitive to industries such as heating, which has recently implemented efficiency labelling. Finally, this readjustment will seek to avoid new cases such as 'dieselgate', which must occur under real conditions of use and not in laboratory tests.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: Mr President! Because of the energy labelling rules adopted in 2010, which we are now strengthening in our treatment today, and because of the strict energy requirements for industry adopted in this Parliament, by 2020 we will have saved the equivalent of the whole of Italy's annual energy consumption. Every household in the EU will save on average around DKK 3 500 on energy bills - per year, mind you! This is the value for the environment, for the climate and for the ordinary European citizen, whether she or he is Danish, Italian, czech or Portuguese. This piece of legislation is an unqualified European success and a success that we are now making greater by strengthening and expanding it. Now we're doing the confusing A+, A++, A+++ brands on refrigerators, washing machines and vacuum cleaners. In future, you will only have to deal with A- to G-marks. Now we are making it even easier both to protect the environment and the climate and to save on electricity bills.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – I am very much in support of moving forward in the area of energy efficiency. Energy efficiency best responds to the key challenges ahead. On the one hand, it reduces Europe's energy dependency, on the one hand. In some ways, I am very pleased that, in these 20 years, when Europe is intensively engaged in this, it has actually run out of these pluses at A, because it is saying that we are going in the right direction and, on the other hand, calling for a change to make such labelling more accurate or clearer for consumers. I therefore support that these codes should be changed to go in grades A to G, that we have once again the possibility of promotion, as we like to say, on the one hand, and, on the other, that the control over the measures implemented will also be effective, because in the past the question has already been asked repeatedly as to whether this information on the labels on these products is accurate. I support these measures.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, energy efficiency policy is linked to decisions in the areas of security of supply, climate change, sustainable development and the internal market. However, as it is today, especially in the countries of the European South, it is important that energy efficiency is primarily aimed at eradicating the shameful phenomenon of energy poverty.  The target set by the Council of the European Union in October 2014 is to increase energy efficiency to 27% by 2030. To do this, providers and sellers in all Member States should provide valid and visible information on the energy efficiency of their products. Consumer confusion must be avoided, but a knowledge-driven transition must also be achieved.  Tackling energy poverty can provide a strong incentive, both to the Member States and to the citizens themselves, to contribute to this energy saving effort and the Commission should find the necessary resources to finance this effort to inform citizens.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Dear President, I would like to support this report and the proposals we have right from the beginning because I really see them as something that will greatly contribute to the manufacturers of various products that we are talking about, but especially consumers. The really confusing thing was that labeling of the energy efficiency that we've had so far and that we have now. Alphabetically, simply, very easy to understand marking is what we really need and in this context I want to express my full support.  However, dear Madam Commissioner, what I would like to ask you is: why not finally come up with such a simple, fully acceptable way of labelling the quality of products or quality of services or efficiency in this single market, in this case energy efficiency? I think that in the single market we should have as unique a way as possible to mark the quality of services and products.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I think, having been involved in COP 21 in Paris last year it was a wonderful occasion – the first time ever we have had a global agreement, probably in anything. So all countries are now moving to help reduce greenhouse gas emissions and keep the temperature of global warming below 2 degrees, moving to 1.5 degrees. And every facet of human activity has to come into that. Energy efficiency is a key area and I think a lot more can be done and I am glad now we are getting down to the details on it. We have our targets but now we are getting down to the details, especially in bringing consumers with us who want to make a contribution, who want to save the planet and want, obviously, to reduce their bills. The idea of anything with an A attached to it means it is the best, whether it is A+ or A++, that is only a detail. I think moving to the new classification makes far more sense and will be far simpler for consumers, which they will appreciate and will help us reach those targets which is so vital. Well done to everybody.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I want to thank you for this very useful debate. I think there is a strong consensus and there is indeed a strong support to revise the energy label and make it more efficient in order to facilitate for the consumer. Just a few words on the database. It is not going to be a huge administrative burden. It is actually only creating an obligation on manufacturers and importers to register the product model by uploading information that is already required under the different existing delegated acts. The technical documentation will only be accessible to market surveillance authorities, so thereby the data security will be secured. The Commission already has experience with such databases, for instance in cosmetics. And regarding the costs, the actual costs could in fact be less than today because manufacturers no longer need to keep technical documentation available for market surveillance authorities for five years after the last product was manufactured. So hopefully this will be a useful tool for consumers, and not an extra burden. I agree that we need more, better and simpler standards for the whole of the internal market. Unfortunately, we cannot solve that particular problem here today, but today we can send a strong signal that we are agreeing to do something important, to facilitate for the consumers, to do important work here to revise energy labelling and the Commission very much looks forward to continuing working with the European Parliament to finalise this proposal, and again I want to thank the rapporteur and the different shadow rapporteurs for the work that has been done here.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner and all my fellow Members for the journey they have taken together, for their appreciation and also for the criticisms they have received. Criticism has also been useful in achieving a report that is as balanced as possible. In these months, while we were writing this report, I was drawing up my proposal and then in the subsequent negotiations I had in mind an image, a dream: the idea of label 2.0 and what is possible, thanks to the reform of the label and a QR code and a database.  So I imagined that one day I myself could happen in an appliance store and maybe see our new label in operation and see some European citizens, as can australian citizens for many years, point with their mobile phone the QR code and compare, thanks to applications, more products, by virtue of the consumption characteristics and compare them not only on pre-established consumption patterns but also on patterns that are those of his own and his family and to be able to obtain from an app, imaginary for the moment but that will certainly come, information on the actual costs of consuming that device in monetary terms, related precisely to its actual consumption and therefore be able to choose the device that best meets the needs and that allows to recover investments in more efficient and more expensive devices , also knowing how long. This is one of the examples of the label that I imagined and that I hope to see as soon as possible in the real world and let us say that Europe needs a small success story at the moment because I hope that we will be able to move forward and move forward together.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. Today's vote on energy efficiency labelling is an important milestone, coming at the end of a long process that has seen me at the forefront of the Committee on the Environment and the Committee on industry. This work has certainly borne fruit, and I say this with great satisfaction: the text produced today by the plenary follows the progress and improvements made to the Commission's original text during the work of the two parliamentary committees, in which we had managed to achieve important results in various respects. With the return to a single A-G scale for all products, we have tried to give clarity to the energy label again in the eyes of consumers; we have established clear and predictable criteria for the periodic updating of labels, so-called 're-heating', to be implemented in line with the degree of technological development of each product group and in such a way as to ensure durability and representativeness of the label; we have included more detailed and stringent forecasts of market surveillance and product compliance checks. I welcome the fact that the text adopted in Strasbourg does, however, provide for certain innovations, such as the possibility of including in the labels the reference to 'intelligent equipment', which is interconnected and capable of guaranteeing greater energy savings.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: in writing. – More and more household appliances are being used and 85% of European consumers take energy labelling into account in their purchasing decisions, so their acceptance is widespread in all countries of the Union. It is a guarantee for the consumer, while being an instrument for achieving emission reduction targets, improving energy efficiency and reducing fuel dependence. The proposed new labelling eliminates confusing A+ categories and sets a single scale from A to G more simplified. By 2020, fuel savings from the use of energy efficiency labels are estimated to be equivalent to 180 million tonnes of oil. The 27% energy efficiency improvement target by 2030 is an unjustifiable target, so this figure should be increased to 40% The unjustified delay of up to five years in full implementation of the new regulation can lead to lower investments in research and improvements by manufacturers and should therefore be minimized for the benefit of all.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, I am very pleased to support the report on a new regulation on energy labelling of household appliances and products. Labelling policy has so far resulted in energy savings commensurate with annual energy consumption in Italy, one of the major countries of the European Union. Unfortunately, the existing labelling scale has exhausted its capabilities, since almost 90% of household appliances already fall at the top of the scale marked A with a series of "+". I welcome the return to the easily understandable 7-letter scale (A to G) with seven different colors (from dark green to red). The scale reformatting mechanism provided for in the Regulation for existing products will allow for a shift within a period of 5 years to the new stricter energy efficiency requirements for own production and household appliances imported into the Union. I fully support the criteria for rock conversion as technology advances and the market is saturation with energy-efficient products in the highest class. The extended requirements for the provision of information to consumers and advertising materials, as well as the increased role of market surveillance authorities in complying with the requirements of the new Regulation, will contribute to achieving the high targets for reducing energy consumption in our households.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the joint debate on: – a report by Eleanor Forenza, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on the implementation of Parliament's 2010 recommendations on social and environmental standards, Human Rights and Business Responsibility (2015/2038(INI)) (A8-0217/2016) and – a report by Tiziana Beghin on behalf of the Committee on International Trade on a new forward-looking and innovative future trade and investment strategy (2015/2105(INI)) (A8-0220/2016).

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the report I am going to present concerns, in my opinion, fundamental aspects of the European Union's trade policy, namely the relationship between international trade and human rights, social rights, environmental standards and corporate social responsibility. It seems to me that the report makes a clear request to the Commission: effective and binding respect for human rights, defence and raising of social and environmental standards cannot be subordinated to trade competition and investment defence, nor entrusted to the ideology of deregulation as a driver of growth. All too often we have seen – and this is also the thrust of the report – a major discrepancy between the verbal affirmation of rights and their effective defence and application.  Let us therefore try to give concrete indications on how to relaunch, through trade policy, the commitment made by the Union to promote and protect human, social and environmental rights, together with democracy and the rule of law. We cannot continue as if nothing had happened. Brexit, as well as the growing distrust of the peoples of Europe towards this European Union, should have given a clear signal about the need for discontinuity. Discontinuity without which the European project itself is in danger of foundering. In my opinion, there is also a necessary discontinuity in trade policy, at a time when the negotiations, which could have enormous consequences for the lives of the women and men of Europe, negotiations such as TTIP and CETA, give rise to legitimate concerns, which are increasingly widespread in public opinion, also on the issues covered by this report: human rights, social and environmental standards. More generally, we could say, the relationship between trade development and democracy.  For this reason too, Madam Commissioner, I would like to make a parenthesis. We believe that it is deeply wrong, for example, not to involve the national parliaments in the ratification of CETA: we need more democracy and more participation and not less democracy and less participation. We know that the Eu ropean Union plays a crucial role in world trade: as the world's largest exporter of goods and services and the main source of foreign direct investment, the Union takes a leading position in the global market, both through its participation in the WTO and through its trade and investment agreements, which have helped to build an important part of that extremely complex and contradictory process that we call globalisation. Globalisation, which at the time of the crisis is having unequal effects both between and within countries, and the role that the European Union can play in this respect is central.  This Parliament has repeatedly expressed the need for trade policy not only to have the benefit of a few companies as an objective but to be an element of a strategy of international relations, aimed at promoting respect for human and social rights and environmental protection. In order to do this, and this is precisely the aim of this report, for the first time in the Committee on International Trade, a report has resulted from a reflection on the impact and follow-up of three reports previously adopted in 2010, while at the same time providing an assessment and guidance to the Commission in the implementation of our trade policy. It was a long process of discussion and mediation, a rigorous discussion with the other shadow rapporteurs, whom I would like to thank here, as well as the rapporteurs for ducks from the AFET, DEVE, FEMM and EMPL committees.  The report also provides guidance on a number of key issues which I would like to outline briefly here. Firstly, on the need for legislative coherence. The Union's trade policies must be developed in line with policies on social protection, development, human rights and the environment. We affirm the centrality of a gender reading of impact assessments and trade policy choices and it is from the perspective of gender mainstreaming, which we are also working on in the Committee on International Trade, that we want a policy that is finally gender sensitive and no longer gender blind.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, what is international trade? All too often, following the debates in this Parliament, I had the impression that it was an objective in itself, a goal. But colleagues, no! Trade is not the goal, it is just a means of achieving other goals. Trade is not the goal, but the race, the race for greater prosperity, equality and social progress for all. That is why the document we want to guide the European Union's trade policy begins with this idea and continues to lay down the conditions for the world's leading trading power to fulfil its role with responsibility, courage and care for its citizens and for all the citizens of the world. Trade is not the end, but it is the means. As rapporteur, I am very proud of this first message, but it is the content of the resolution that makes me truly proud. Of course, it is a compromise text, but the fact remains that, by a large majority in committee, we have approved a number of demands and priorities to make trade policy more transparent, accountable and effective. We have recognised the opportunities for trade and we have called for a trade policy that works for small and medium-sized enterprises, that creates opportunities for foreign markets for our farmers, for our service providers and, not least, for our industry, with agreements that bring tangible benefits for citizens, perhaps exploring new markets. I am thinking in particular of Australia and New Zealand, but also mercosur and Africa. We know that trade is not just an opportunity and it is not always a victory on all fronts. That is why we have called on the Commission and the Member States to implement support policies in favour of the so-called losers of globalisation, and I personally think that this is another opportunity for reflection on social policies that disconnect income from work, such as minimum income or citizenship. But prevention is better than cure. That is why the resolution clearly talks about the importance of accurate impact studies, both ex ante and ex post, and of reforming trade defence instruments, clearly opposing the granting of market economy status to China, but also talking about the defence of geographical indications and the fight against counterfeiting, in order to protect European excellence in the world.  I am also very proud of all the paragraphs that insist on our responsibility for fair trade, respectful of rights and oriented towards compliance with the Sustainable Development Goals. Now all the products we use every day, from cars to mobile phones, are the result of a production chain that crosses the whole world, with a small part of the value that is added in every country. With this document, the European Parliament is calling loudly for these global supply chains to be clean, sustainable and respectful; that there is a respect for due diligence, to know whether the good you buy is stained with blood or not, whether it was produced by forced child labour or by violating human rights. And we did not stop there, because we called for the sustainability of trade to also apply to the environment and animals, demanding greater control with regard to compliance with the rules for trade in protected species and farm animals.  In order to ensure that these commitments are kept by our partners, we are calling loudly for the new free trade treaties to contain binding chapters on sustainable development with clear sanction mechanisms for those who do not respect their commitments in terms of respect for rights and the environment and with investigations, which we want to be launched at the request of the European Parliament. Of course, the great opportunities for trade must be built on solid foundations, which are the protection of European consumers and environmental, health and social standards. This also passes as desired by the resolution through further reflections on those treaties and systems, such as the ISDS and ICS, which could make the interests of the powerful few prevail over those of many citizens.  Citizens must be able to assess freely and at all times whether they are properly protected. That is why we are calling on the Commission to step up its efforts for an increasingly transparent, comprehensible and citizen-viewable trade policy, without more documents and secret meetings. In addition, we also make a clear appeal to the Council to make parliament's consultation systematic in the preparation of negotiating mandates and to binding its opinion, and also to call for the publication of all approved mandates.  Finally, the new media have multiplied the possibilities for participation and citizens' control over the political life of the institutions. That is why I come from a movement that makes direct democracy its flag, I would like to end my speech with the hope that the Commission will be able to engage more and more exchanges and dialogues with citizens on trade policy and use the Internet and the new media to account more and more accurately for its commercial choices, thus making direct sure of the opinion of those who are the first stake-holders , that is, the citizens.  Who knows that one day even the negotiations for international treaties, instead of being carried out behind closed doors, will not be streamed and that trade policy will not become the first area of application of almost direct democracy. Given the time, maybe, this may seem like a dream but it's definitely a nice dream. Finally, I would like to thank all my fellow Members for their active work and cooperation.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking the Committee on International Trade and especially the two rapporteurs, Ms Forenza and Ms Beghin, for their work on these two very important reports. Sustainable development in trade policy is an area where Parliament and the Commission clearly share an interest and a strong engagement. The Commission’s new trade policy, the Trade for All strategy, has sustainable development at its core. It sets out an ambitious and comprehensive agenda for the EU, underlining the fact that trade is not only about economic growth but also about defending the values that we share in Europe: social justice, respect for human rights, and high labour and environmental standards. This strategy builds upon progress already achieved since the adoption by the European Parliament in 2010 of the three resolutions in this area: first, the introduction of binding and comprehensive trade and sustainable development chapters in all our free trade agreements; second, the strengthening of the human rights dimension, including gender, in our sustainable impact assessment; and, third, reforming the EU Generalised System of Preferences, including the flagship GSP+, sustainable development and good governance. We also have developed partnerships with key players to promote change in countries where the situation was acute, for example through the Bangladesh Compact. Furthermore, we are supporting responsible business practices, including enhanced transparency for large companies on non-financial information, as well as the uptake in implementation of internationally recognised guidelines and principles of corporate social responsibility. The EU has been a frontrunner over recent years in pursuing the integration of sustainable development into its policy, and this engagement has also been recognised by many international organisations and our trading partners. But being a frontrunner is, of course, not enough. There is much more work to be done. In this regard we have set some priorities, notably the effective implementation of trade and sustainable development chapters, better linking trade policy instruments to development cooperation, including with a view to supporting the 2030 agenda, and the promotion of responsible supply chains and of private sector engagement to integrate sustainable development objectives as part of core business strategies. The report on a new forward-looking and innovative future strategy for trade and investment underlines the importance of pushing both jobs and growth, as well as the value agenda that focused on human rights, good governance and sustainable development. We have taken very careful note of the request for our future trade policy to have a stronger focus not only on these issues but also on manufacturing priorities and services. Trade in manufacturing is, of course, a priority, as it has been in recent decades and will be in the future as well. It is a central pillar of our market access strategy in trade agreements and trade defence. The Commission welcomes the attention given to the importance of coherence between trade and other EU policies, and this new Commission is working hard, along these lines, to integrate the various policy areas – respect for human and labour rights, protection of the environment, and the development of partner countries, including sustainable development chapters – in all our trade agreements. We very much welcome Parliament’s emphasis on the primacy of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) system and the multilateral approach to negotiation. I share the ambition in that regard. We agree that the multilateral route for trade liberalisation is of course the most efficient and the most equitable, when it is possible. Moreover, we endorse Parliament’s demand for a balanced outcome, including on agriculture, in free trade agreements. We will continue, in this context, to balance the needs of manufacturing, services and agricultural producers in setting our priorities for negotiation. We also take note of the view expressed on market economy status for China. As you know, the Commission is currently conducting an in-depth impact assessment analysing the various options with regard to the treatment of China in anti-dumping investigations, and we will hold further political discussions on this in the coming weeks. Lastly, Parliament’s call for greater reciprocity in opening up public procurement is well noted. It is clearly an area where there is imbalance, and we take this very much into account when we formulate mandates and negotiate free trade agreements, in order to have a more level playing field in the area of public procurement. So I want to thank you very much for these reports. They contain some very valuable comments. Much of what you propose is actually already being done by the Commission but we can, of course, do more and we look forward to working with you in order to have not only as efficient a trade policy as possible but also a sustainable and responsible one.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: draftser of the Opinion of the Committee on Development. – Mr President, Mrs Malmstrom, the impunity with which many companies are championed around the world is intolerable.  As rapporteur for the opinion of the DEVE Commission, I consider it essential that the principle of policy coherence, especially in the field of international trade, be respected at once. Also ensure compliance with the United Nations declaration on the right to development as an inalienable right of all and that the sovereignty of States to establish policies that respond to the interests of their people is respected. But above all, a binding treaty is urgently needed for companies to respect social and environmental standards and, above all, human rights. The European Union should support the work of the United Nations in this regard, rather than blocking them. Moreover, our clauses on trade agreements are worthless—see Mexico—and we are tired of seeing unbearable business impunity in the face of their violations.  Terrible world we are building, when we consider it extremist and radical to demand something as basic as multinationals respecting human rights.  Tomorrow, which side are you going to wear, ladies and gentlemen?

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Equal Opportunities. – Mr President, we value the rapporteur's efforts in drawing up this report, in particular as regards the absolute need for respect for and enhancement of labour rights and conditions, as well as the role of the International Labour Organisation. But beyond the recommendations I can make from this Plenary, we do not lose sight of the view that social responsibility is tortured by the large European economic and financial groups: when they promote the relocation of companies and labour and social dumping, when they attack collective bargaining and the organisations representing workers, when they promote the exploitation of resources and workers in third countries by digging social and gender discrimination. It will not be the European Union's trade policy that reverses this reality. This shows that it is time to reject the Treaty of Lisbon also with regard to trade relations and that each country should define its trade policies and agreements compatible with its interests and needs.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: rapporteur for AFET opinion. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Forenza, for our good cooperation on this report. Since 2010, progress has been made by the Commission and trade continues to try to contribute, at the bilateral and multilateral level, to respect for human rights, as well as to social and environmental standards. The human rights clauses in trade agreements, the presence of binding chapters on sustainable development and the Commission's action on the international stage must continue and be strengthened. In this sense, we must call on the WTO, as part of its reform, to take more account of social and environmental standards. The actions of the European Union must go further. For example, we need to pay close attention to the GSP system and improve it so that the conventions are truly respected. On the other hand, some initiatives need to be pursued. I am referring here to the sustainability pact, launched in the wake of the Rana Plaza tragedy. The Commission must continue its corporate social responsibility policy and extend this type of action to other trading partners. I would also like to raise a request that had already been made in 2010 and to which no further action has been taken. The Commission must present a legislative initiative as soon as possible that will put an end to child and forced labour. I would like to stress the importance of the effective implementation of the agreements and commitments that have been made in a transparent manner. It is important that Parliament be more included in the follow-up process. With regard to the Union's trade strategy, I thank Mrs Beghin for her work. It is essential that the spirit of reciprocity and mutual benefit be at the heart of the European Union's trade relations with its partners. Particular attention should be paid to sensitive products, particularly agricultural products, with the implementation of specific and appropriate treatments. Finally, as rapporteur on the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, I would like to point out that trade policy must protect and promote the values defended by the European Union. We also encourage the Commission to continue its communication efforts with the citizen and to increase access to negotiating documents.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development. – Mr President, with all due respect to our colleagues in the different political groups and with different opinions, I cannot give the green light to the attitude which I feel is contrary to our EU trade strategies, by politicising the trade agenda too much. I believe that human rights and trade are not contradictory, but complementary. I believe that trade is a key development instrument that brings growth and wealth, and therefore in the long term contributes to the development of human, labour and social rights. I stand for the strategy of engagement, instead of the policy of conditionality. I believe that we should treat our counterparts as trading partners on an equal footing, and that this kind of treatment will bring a solid basis for ongoing dialogue and cooperation. One free trade agreement in particular, that has only recently been concluded, the free trade agreement between the EU and Vietnam, could serve as a very good example of that approach. I think that developing countries need social, labour and environmental standards that correspond in the first place with their level of economic and social development, and any effort to bring binding requirements, to impose binding requirements, which unfortunately is an attitude becoming more and more popular in this Chamber, means that it will be harmful to them. It will be counterproductive and also de facto this means a certain exporting of protectionism from our side, and this is something that I cannot support.

name: Joachim SCHUSTER
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which With its new trading strategy, the Commission also claims to promote value-based trading. However, it still does not fully live up to this claim, even though it is now customary for trade agreements to contain sustainability chapters with workers' rights. However, many of the sustainability chapters are insufficiently formulated: effective dispute resolution mechanisms are often lacking. And even if the agreements are well formulated, the reality often deviates from the treaty texts later on. That is why, among other things, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs calls for the parties to commit themselves in all trade agreements in future to ratify and implement the eight core labour standards of the ILO, to carry out comprehensive impact assessments and to actively counteract negative effects on jobs and workers' rights, to ensure that labour mobility in trade in services does not lead to the dismantling of social rights and labour protection rights, and for mandatory monitoring with the full involvement of civil societies. , in particular the trade unions.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – Mr President, nationalisms and populism threaten the pillars of society and democracy in the European Union. A strong response is needed to achieve more and better Europe. It is therefore essential to turn trade policy around, so that citizens perceive that trade agreements serve to improve their quality of life and to promote European values around the world. Human rights provisions and social, labour, environmental standards should be legally binding and public services excluded from negotiations. But they are of no use to laudable objectives if compliance and evaluation are not possible. I welcome the Commission's communication, but I believe that there are some notable absences, as Mrs Beghin's report says: not to use trade policy to promote gender equality in the world, not to incorporate specific measures for SMEs to take full advantage of the benefits of trade agreements and greater coordination between trade and industrial policy. I think progress has been made, but it is true that there is a long way to go to achieve fair and equitable trade. And I would like to end by thanking the two rapporteurs for their excellent work and the effort they have made in search of consensus.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Mr President, so what do we expect from the new trade strategy? Well, first of all, it must not be business as usual. On the one hand, we are seeing more and more EU citizens interested in trade issues. However, on the other hand, there are increasing numbers of those concerned and fearful of the potential impact of the trade issues. We have to be able to come up with new ways to communicate these issues more effectively and to address citizens’ concerns. This would mean saying a clear ‘no’ to all forms of protectionism while aiming for trade that is both fair and responsible. I am convinced that a proper implementation of the strategy should start with an inventory of all current trade negotiations. For this to occur you would need to reallocate sufficient human resources within the Commission services. The EU does not show itself to be very serious about this, when we see negotiations taking more than 12 or 15 years. We need to have clear priorities and deliver. Personally, I see three key areas for our future trade policy. They should consist of: first, promoting a digital dimension of international trade; secondly, facilitating exchange in the services sector; and lastly, providing our companies, especially SMEs, with real new business opportunities. The success of our trade policy will ultimately be measured by how well EU companies can access foreign markets and how effectively we can respond to their daily problems.

name: Esther HERRANZ GARCÍA
text: draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. – Mr President, I would first like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and the rapporteur for this report for taking into account the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture, given that the agricultural sector is precisely one of the most sensitive chapters of trade negotiations with third countries.  Free trade agreements can bring many benefits, but they can also seriously jeopardize the future of certain vulnerable agricultural sectors, for which the necessary exclusion clauses or mitigation measures need to be provided. This accumulation of concessions can be particularly harmful in areas such as fruit and vegetables or in sectors such as poultry or beef.  Agriculture has already been, on many occasions, the currency of exchange of trade negotiations with third countries, a circumstance that should not be repeated in the future.  On the other hand, one of the Union's main goals in negotiations with third countries should be the introduction of an equivalence ratio or, if possible, the full reciprocity of health standards, as well as the elimination of non-tariff barriers, which constitute the real obstacle to trade with many countries above tariff barriers.  Finally, I would just like to stress the importance for the European Union's brand image of the protection of appellations of origin and geographical indications in third countries, so this should be an indispensable condition in the agricultural negotiations of trade agreements.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I have three issues. First of all I have a general problem with the notion that free trade is naturally beneficial to the EU and that it automatically brings prosperity and jobs. I do not oppose free trade as such but I do not like how easily we have come to accept that free trade is good as some self-evident truth. The second point I would like to make is that there is a general lack of knowledge about EU trade policy on the part of our constituencies. This prevents our trade policy from being effective. Outside of Brussels, people and companies find out about our trade policy initiatives too late to be able to influence the outcome. We must find a way to inform them of our trade initiatives in time so they can fully participate and shape these policies. And finally, we need to have a mechanism to verify the input of the Brussels trade associations so that they truly represent EU industry and they speak on behalf of EU industry. We have to be certain that these associations really represent the interests of our domestic industries.

name: David MARTIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the S&D Group welcomed the Commission’s communication, Trade for All, and in particular its shift towards a value-based trade. But frankly, words on paper are easy and now we need to see the Commission deliver on its promises, and we are not convinced that the current trade negotiations are truly reflecting these new values. We agree that under certain conditions trade can bring sustainable growth and jobs – for instance, we have just had the fifth anniversary of the EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement, where EU exports to Korea have increased by 55% helping to turn a trade deficit into a trade surplus. This is a significant achievement and our companies and workers have benefited from that. However, as a previous speaker has just said, we cannot ignore that trade does not benefit all. It is therefore essential we make sure the benefits of trade reach the widest range of people. This is why open trade has to be accompanied by adequate flanking policies, including access to a reformed Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The losers from trade liberalisation cannot and should not be left alone. My group has always pushed for FTAs to be used as levers to promote EU values, and as such we welcome the reference to sustainable development, human rights, fair and ethical trade and the fight against corruption and tax evasion. And in this respect we reiterate in the report that the trade and sustainable development chapters in our FTAs should be enforceable in order to make sure our trading partners effectively implement those rules. And we agree with the Commissioner that the proliferation of FTAs should not lead to the death of the multilateral trading system. For us, the WTO is still the priority as it guarantees the poorest countries can take full advantage of trade liberalisation and make full use of its participation in international trade by consistent trade rules across the global community.

name: Emma McCLARKIN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur as well for her support for this trade strategy and the free trade agreements that it champions within. This trade report represents a strong mandate for opening up and developing global trading relations. It provides a solid steer for pursuing trade that delivers for consumers across Europe. While I would have hoped for a more positive tone with fewer reservations and red lines laid down, on the whole it is a step in the right direction and I am pleased to see a recognition of the role that competition plays in benefiting consumers, the importance of chasing offensive interests such as public procurement access and investment, and, importantly , a greater appreciation of the region of Latin America and helping our SMEs reap the benefits of this region. Areas of concern still remain within this trade strategy: protectionist measures in the form of a retaliatory public procurement instrument and continual insistence on GI protection for non-agricultural products. I believe that both these measures display a protectionist agenda and that this will provoke a defensive response. This will be to the detriment of opening up new markets and our EU offensive interests in negotiations. The EU needs a positive, ambitious and liberal trade agenda to ensure that trade deals are not only continually opened and negotiated, but are also delivered and ratified. Only in this way can the EU show that it is serious about jobs and growth.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, trade is an increasingly important element of the various EU foreign policy instruments. It is a way to leverage the single market on the global stage, to strengthen the rules-based and values-based system and to make sure that trade rules help stronger standards, considering people and planners. In a world which is rapidly changing, with the economic rise of countries like China or the Gulf states that do not share our standards and levels of openness, this is not a luxury, but a necessity. I am glad to see that the Commission has ensured values are at the heart of the EU’s trade strategy. Clearly, this is what EU citizens expect. The interest in, and the debate about, trade have increased significantly over the past years. It is not without reason that Member State governments, as well as parliamentarians, decided to leverage the weight of our entire European economy on the global stage to have the best negotiating position. I certainly hope that these governments, as well as national parliaments, will continue to play an active role because it is too easy to pretend it is ‘Brussels’ dreaming up trade policy or ‘Brussels’ not publishing documents, while we constantly have to push for Member States to make mandate texts available, for example. In addition, there is a huge demand by people to have their voices heard. It is key that the capacity to engage people actively is created. We must do what we can but trade ministers at the national level, as well as parliaments, are perhaps the best positioned to address sector-specific and regional elements of trade. If there are negative impacts to be mitigated, policies must be made nationally. I believe that only when we play each of our roles and when we work together, do we ensure transparency and engagement with a clear view of what is at stake, not only in the EU but globally.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. International trade policy has reached the public consciousness with the EU-wide debates on TTIP, CETA, TiSA and the Economic Partnership Agreements at the latest. That is why this joint debate is only to be welcomed. The Commission has presented an ambitious work programme and now the long-standing strategy for the coming years. That is why it is all the more urgent for the European Parliament to adopt its position on this. I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Beghin, for her efforts. The report by my group colleague, Mr Forenza, is a report of initiative for review into the extent to which important, central demands of Parliament on social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility have been and will be taken into account by the Commission in its trade policy practice in the past and present. In this link in content, the content of the two reports, for me, is closely linked. The GUE/NGL vision of future international trade relations builds on our vision of solidarity, economic justice and fair trade relations. We have re-set out our proposal for an alternative resolution, because the INTA resolution only partially covers what is needed today. We certainly welcome the growing importance that aspects of fair trade are also being given by the European Commission. Nevertheless, the basic concept of trade strategy remains to promote interests and profits for the large transnational companies in production with huge technological upheavals, both in the service sector and in the eu's financial markets, at the expense of the other regions of the world and also, in fact, by small and medium-sized enterprises in the EU itself. That is why all my fellow Members, including the Commission and the Council, should take seriously the alternative trade mandate, which sets out other choices that many NGOs have drawn up. Let us get to work together! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I will agree with you that particular attention should be paid to social aspects in the case of trade strategies. So much so that the tax part of the report itself says that tax avoidance or exploiting the opportunities offered by tax havens is not compatible with socially responsible behaviour – so far we agree. I would ask you if you see the possibility that tax havens should not only be forgotten, but also banned outright within the European Union – because many of our Member States are still tax havens against each other.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Quite rightly so. I can only agree with you that tax havens should be dried up and that is why it is a holistic policy approach that we need. We must not look away from the framework conditions for international trade in economic policy or in the efforts to achieve a common economic policy. That kind of belongs together, yes! But we also need to look at who and which companies use tax havens, and that is why the issue of a common regulation of fiscal conditions is a prerequisite for making social standards. And let's be honest!

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, thank you and thanks also to the rapporteurs for their very fruitful cooperation. We Greens think that trade can be an important instrument to help development cooperation, to promote human rights and for better environmental protection. But I say ‘can’ because I think that there is a potential but this potential is far from being fulfilled. Quite the opposite actually, because trade currently and at the moment often increases inequality and leads to poverty, and that urgently needs to change. I think actually your trade strategy, Commissioner, is a step in the right direction. But now we need to move onwards from the nice words about human rights and values towards the implementation, and that needs to include also binding rules. But instead, what we see the Commission doing is proposing trade sanctions against partner countries that are not readmitting migrants. So instead of having trade sanctions on human rights violations we are actually sanctioning countries who are not closing their border enough and I really hope that colleagues will join me in saying that this is just outright wrong. Also it is absolutely urgent to readjust our trade policy so that it contributes to social justice and equality and security in Europe. Trade must contribute to human rights and to development, it must be coherent with those policies both in Europe as well as abroad on both sides of the deal.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Let me give a different and slightly less real-world view of trade than the one we have just heard from the Greens. In 1990, world trade accounted for 19% of world GDP. That was a total value of $3.5 billion. Today it represents 30% of world GDP and the value overall has more than fivefold. At that time, 38% of the world's population lived in absolute poverty. Today, 10% of the world's population lives in absolute poverty. So it has been halved twice, but it is not just that there is an absolute and causal connection there. Trade in a well-being (inaudible word) eradicates poverty. The problem we have is that this development is slowing down. Trade growth today and late 2008 is less than half that of the average since 1990. And unfortunately, this is very much due to protectionism. Since 2008, when almost 3800 protectionist measures have been introduced worldwide, and at the same time only a third as many trade facilitations have been implemented. Since 1995 to 2008, the average duty was halved from 19% to 10%, but since then it has remained at almost the same level and that is why the Commission's trade strategy is so important in reversing this trend, but then it has to take advantage of all the important issues that you write about. To actually take the fight against trade barriers. Complicated rules of origin, for example. Lighten up trade in services, create freer data flows because we must free (inaudible words) trade and, above all, we must not fall to all those who in this Chamber are calling for more barriers to trade. Because it will cost human lives in poor countries.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, the UK referendum showed that many people are increasingly uneasy with globalisation, feeling that its benefits are unevenly shared. The EU often gets the blame for this, but I think it is part of the solution. Our report sets out tools to ensure that we can trade more fairly, reducing human and environmental exploitation here and abroad, creating virtuous trade relations, progress at home and enabling our trading partners to reach equal or better levels of human development as ours. This report offers concrete proposals to make sustainable development operational, and I will highlight just five of them.  The first is making trade union and civil society engagement more formal, giving greater responsibility to non-state actors, such as the ability to lodge labour rights complaints directly with the Commission. The second, shifting from voluntary corporate social responsibility to effective and enforceable supply chain due diligence requirements, allowing us to build on the recent political agreement on EU legislation on conflict minerals. The third, properly recognising independent expertise by taking impact assessments seriously and undertaking them in a timely manner able to influence negotiations. Fourth, using incentives but equally having adequate deterrents, notably through clear criteria to grant and withdraw GSP+ privileges, which requires, in our view, a new delegated act specifically on this point. And fifthly, involving fully the ILO in all trade talks and negotiations as we did with some success in the aftermath of the terrible Rana Plaza disaster in Bangladesh.  Sustainable development must be enforceable. It must be visible and it cannot just be aspirational. The public will remain distrustful of trade policy until fairness is ingrained and delivered, and that should now be your priority.

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: Thank you to Mrs Beghin for her report. I appreciate the focus on labour rights, public health and the environment, but I regret that the report is stuck in the blind belief in free trade.  How can you think that it makes the world more beautiful and better and more social when we are just pursuing economic goals? It is a lot better for the environment if our products are not dragged hundreds or even thousands of kilometres. It is better for our communities when local entrepreneurs can make a living locally. Of course, we live in a global village, and I don't want to deny anyone his cotton, his coffee, his computer. But there is a difference between trading because it makes everyone better and elevates trade to an end in itself, and I miss that insight in this report.  Finally, the investment court system must not be contrary to the European legal order. That is also in this INI report, and that is good, but it is not enough. I therefore hope that you will support a request to the European Court of Justice for an opinion on this conflict.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, I think we are at a very important time concerning really integrating our values into our interests in trade policy. We have the excellent communication from Commissioner Malmström on trade for all, and we have the Agenda 2030, the so—called Sustainable Development Goals. There are clearly two big challenges. Companies deserve for the EU to actively support all kinds of initiatives on the sustainability and accountability of supply chains, because no company today can afford to be caught employing forced labour in their sub—contracting or child labour, or the like. Secondly, I believe that the EU has a big role in creating the enabling the environment for sustainable development in our trading partner countries. We can draw conclusions in our trade agreements on how to fight against corruption, how to make governments more accountable and how to help the freedom of civil society.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Mr President, the Commission recognises the link between trade, human rights and social and environmental standards. Trade and foreign investments are indeed important tools in achieving economic growth, sustainable development and protection of human rights, which we expect from the Commission and the Council with regard to the implementation of the new trade strategy. At the multilateral level, the Commission should take a leading role in the reform of WTO governance. In particular, the WTO should reform its trade policy review mechanisms in order to include social, environmental and human rights dimensions. It is important that the Commission and the Council both promote regular in-depth monitoring of the implementation of the human rights clauses in trade and association agreements. Our Parliament should also be more actively involved and consulted in this respect. Clearly our trade policy should be a way to encourage EU partner countries to adopt higher social and environmental standards. On the other hand, EU companies abroad should comply with all their obligations, particularly with international standards in the areas of human rights, labour and the environment.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Mr President, it is no secret that the speeches that have just taken place bear witness to this, there is a great deal of fear and scepticism about the Union's trade policy. And it is not, contrary to what I have heard on the benches of the right, a communication problem. This is the reality experienced by people. They note that, in the context of liberal globalization, widespread free trade often benefits the same people. They say, "There are winners and there are losers," but the truth is that it is often the same winners, that is, big business, and the losers, we know them: industry, peasant agriculture and public services, which are systematically dismantled. Both reports are moving in the right direction, of course; they outline what might be called "fair trade," fair trade, but you have to be specific about a number of things.  First, the proliferation of bilateral negotiations is not necessarily a guarantee of success and progress. Sometimes you have to hurry slowly. Second, and just as importantly, you have to have the courage to protect yourself. Yes, we must protect European industry. Yes, sensitive agriculture must be protected. Finally, we have to base our policy on values - that has been said very well by my colleagues, but there is still a lot of progress to be made.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Trade for everyone! For me, as a Social Democrat, this means that profit and prosperity are distributed fairly among all in our society, that the standard of living of all is improved and that not only a few benefit from it. A responsible trade policy and investment policy involves workers and consumers, i.e. all citizens, and also opens up more opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises in world trade. Responsible policies support and promote and protect EU values such as democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights. It is essential that the principles of responsibility and sustainability are enshrined in all trade agreements. Demanding workers, social and environmental standards with sanction mechanisms must be included. In order for these commitments to be effectively honoured, the possibilities for control by civil society and stakeholders are needed. I expect the Commission and the Council to finally take our demands seriously and implement them.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, the Commission's trade strategy is announced as being for all and based on values, which naturally justifies the support of this Parliament. But aligning the trade agenda with sustainable development is not just words, it has to be made of contractual clauses and concrete measures. The European Union has a duty to use its trade weight in favour of sustainable development worthy of that name and this is particularly true in its strategic partnership with the ACP countries that now define its post-2020 framework.  I therefore ask the Commission to listen to this Parliament and to ensure that existing or negotiated trade agreements are monitored and evaluated and to ensure the participation of civil society and the involvement of this Parliament in this assessment. Because only then can we be sure that, beyond words, the Union's trade agenda serves sustainable development and deserves the trust of citizens.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, táimse i mo bhall de Choiste INTA agus táim ar an gcoiste sin d’aon ghnó. Blianta ó shin ní raibh mórán éilimh ar an gcoiste sin ach anois tá fonn ar a lán Feisirí a bheith ar an gcoiste toisc an tábhacht a thuigimid a bhaineann leis an straitéis a bhaineann le trádáil.  Tá sé simplí; más féidir le tíortha níos mó trádála a bheith acu le tíortha eile beidh níos mó easpórtála, beidh níos mó jabanna agus beidh níos mó airgid ann. Dá bhrí sin táim i bhfabhar na gcomhaontuithe saorthrádála atá againn. Chríochnaíomar ceann le Vítneam roimh Nollaig – bhíos ann – agus bhí ríméid orthu faoi agus cabhróidh sé leo agus linn.  Luadh an comhaontú a bhí againn leis an gCóiré. Ach dar ndóigh tá sé tábhachtach go leanfaimid ar aghaidh agus go dtabharfaimid cead don Choimisiún leanúint ar aghaidh taobh istigh den straitéis atá againn go háirithe mar a bhaineann le cearta sibhialta, sóisialta agus comhshaoil.  Go leana sibh ar aghaidh leis na comhaontuithe agus na hidirbheartaíochtaí go léir.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, Madam Commissioner, I believe you already have a document that will help you here. It is a 20-page document called the Alternative Trade Mandate and it says trade should be about exchange with ecologically and culturally distinct regions, equitably sharing their product skills and creativity. This document was produced in 2014 and was welcomed by this Parliament before I was elected. It was put together through consultation with more than 50 civil society organisations, including trade unions, and I believe you need to return to that document. Many of us endorsed it during our election campaigns and many more have come to use its messages and continue to work with the organisations that supported it, so I urge you to return to the document and try and uphold those principles.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear President, the European Union prides itself on a high level of human and civil rights and rightly wants all its political, military and trading partners to share the same values and standards. The question, of course, is how to achieve this. I think using trade policy for these purposes we do the most harm to ourselves. China, Russia, the Gulf states: none of them provides protection of human and civil rights at the level at which the European Union does. Nevertheless, we trade with them, but we do not want to sign free trade agreements until the human rights situation in these countries improves. This is the hypocritical attitude that harms our citizens and entrepreneurs the most because it makes products from imports more expensive for them, while making our exports and economic expansion more difficult.  If we are already trading with the whole world, even those countries where the human rights situation is at a low level, then let's look at how to facilitate this trade, and for human rights we fight in other ways.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – This debate reflects the profound contradictions of a neoliberal system based on free trade and on the basis of a purely mercantile logic, which subjugates everything and everyone in the name of profit. As reality shows, it will not be through vague and non-binding rules that we will improve the fate of those who are exploited inside and outside the European Union. What about the human rights safeguard clause in the Association Agreement between Israel and the European Union? Has this agreement ever been called into question, despite the successive human rights violations of palestinian people on their own territory on a daily basis? As long as free trade and the private interests of large enterprises prevail, it will certainly not be the well-intentioned words of this House that impose corporate social responsibility.  That is why we stand for a new model of cooperation mutually beneficial to both sides and with respect for the sovereignty of national states.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, trade is at the core of the European Union. Controlling a third of world trade, the EU is the largest trading bloc in the world and the largest promoter of human rights through trade, but this is not something we should be complacent about. The new engine of global growth is now in Asia, which is also the most dynamic region in world trade. In the future, 90% of global growth in the world will take place outside the EU. This is why, if we want to support jobs in the Union and also defend our position as the main promoters of universal values through trade in the world, we have no time to lose. It is absolutely necessary that we revitalise our existing agreements, ratify as swiftly as possible the ones that have already been concluded, and create a more informed political debate on the ones under negotiation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, so far the Union's strategy on trade and investment policies is supposed to be based on efficiency, transparency and values in order, supposedly, to provide benefits to all citizens of its Member States. In particular, with the Juncker plan, the European Fund for Strategic Investments is projected over the next three years to generate a total of EUR 315 billion of additional investment in the economy.  For Greece, which has been impoverished by the Memorandums, 42 investment projects have already been submitted. However, only two of these projects have been implemented, with the ProCredit Group and Creta Farm. At the same time, the European Union, instead of promoting fair trade for all, is trying through corporate agreements such as TTIR to remove tariff barriers by dismantling European agriculture and favouring multinational companies, to the detriment of small companies and producers.  It is therefore necessary for the European Union to finance the implementation of investment projects in the European South and greece and to put an end to policies such as TTIR.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, as a red line, this debate is about whether fairer trade is possible. I believe, together with my colleagues, that it does, but it must be remembered that it is important that Parliament also fulfils its role in approving trade clauses.  For us, it should also be a certain memento that if a particular market leaves a European business, for example because human rights or certain standards are not respected, it is usually taken up by another entrepreneur who has no regard whatsogging at all. We should remember that, too.  I would also like to point out that human rights can be perceived from several points of view. The first is that they are basic, they are truly universally intrusive. Then there are the next generation of human rights. I do not want to question their scope and enumeration, however, some other geographical areas may perceive the extent of certain social rights quite problematically. For this reason too, I would call for some caution, but at the same time I believe that fairer trade is indeed possible.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the House for this interesting debate. It has been very good and there are a lot of valuable suggestions in the reports by the two rapporteurs. When the Commission presented its Trade for All strategy it had three main objectives. First, of course, that the trade agreements we conclude should have effect: that they should actually bring benefits to our consumers, our citizens and our entrepreneurs. Trade can be a formidable resource in fighting poverty and ensuring that people prosper. Of course, we need to get it right, and this is something that our trade agreements are focusing on. We need to deal with the right issues as well: modern issues, such as services, e—commerce and intellectual property rights (IPR), while defending the very important manufacturing industry that we have in the European Union. We need to make sure that consumers really get the benefits of our trade agreements and that we reach out in a better way to SMEs. We have, for instance, proposed a specific SME website in order to facilitate SMEs’ knowing about the trade agreements we conclude. A second goal was to emphasise the values of the European Union. We cannot solve all the human rights problems on earth through trade agreements, we have to be realistic, but we can contribute – and we can do more by being more comprehensive, by using our various policies, on trade, development, foreign policy, investment etcetera, in a clever way. We can do more and we can enforce those values. We have chapters, in our agreements, on human rights, labour rights and sustainable development: they are enforceable and they are mandatory. We have a dedicated dispute settlement mechanism. And we want to go one step further. For instance, in the newly started negotiations with Mexico, we even have the aim, in the mandate, of fighting corruption. The recent work that we have done jointly – Parliament, the Council and the Commission – to reach conclusions, at least politically, on the conflict minerals agreement and on anti-torture policy is, I think, a good indication that trade can be responsible. The third goal was increased transparency. Citizens want to be engaged, they want to be included, they want to know what trade is about. This is something that has become increasingly acute in recent times and it is mainly to be welcomed but it means that we must change the way that we implement our policy. We have committed to making our trade policy as transparent as possible. With the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), we are taking it as far as possible, and we want to do the same with all other trade agreements. Here, we can do more to engage with citizens.
