This is the task of the Commission, it is the task of Member States and it is also your task: to engage, to explain, to listen, to bring back concerns and questions, and also to give reassurance when it is needed.  We can do more, for instance, on gender equality. It is present in our trade strategy, we take it into account in our impact assessments. In the GSP+ we have included a requirement for observance of the Convention on Non-Discrimination, for instance, but here too we can do more, and I would be happy to look in more detail at your suggestions. Child labour is also an area at which we have been looking. We published a staff working document a few years ago on trade and the worst forms of child labour, and it shows that the worst forms are actually found in non-tradable sectors, so it is difficult to address this. However, we do follow it very closely with our trading partners – we have, for example, the GSP+ monitoring system – and we will continue to do so. Trade is, as I said, debated, and this is good. We need to do more from the Commission side and from Parliament’s side. Member States need to do more to make sure, too, that the trade agreements we conclude are beneficial for our citizens and also complementary vis-à-vis social policy and different protection measures. We are looking now, in the Commission, at how the Globalisation Fund can be used in a more intelligent way to protect people who are not benefiting from globalisation or trade, and we are, of course, reaching out to a number of countries – both developing countries and developed countries – to negotiate trade agreements, and we will continue to do so, while committing to efficiency and transparency and to a value-based trade policy. Thank you very much for this debate. Thank you, honourable Members, for your input. Let us try to work together to make sure that trade is indeed responsible, sustainable and efficient.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would just like to conclude by once again thanking the shadow rapporteurs and those who have spoken for their cooperation, that many of the recommendations that this Parliament made in 2010 have been disregarded by the Commission. Today we are providing precise indications to reiterate one concept: that human, social and environmental rights are not a dependent variable in trade. We call for a reform of the WTO in the direction of ensuring respect for human rights, for the ILO to be a permanent observer of the WTO; we call, for example, for a reformulation of the clause on human rights and sustainable development chapters, so that they are genuinely binding and for the possibility of derogation from trade agreements to be introduced at a time when the real use of human rights is being disregarded.  We are calling for the prior ratification and transposition into national law of the eight plus four fundamental ILO conventions: we know how sensitive this issue is when negotiating TTIP with the United States, which has not signed all of them. We are calling for clear criteria for the identification of environmental assets. We call for action on issues such as current intellectual property regimes. We strongly call for the transition from a voluntary RSI to a binding regulatory framework for multinationals.  As you can see, these are very concrete indications which are designed to reiterate one point: I am sorry to have to contradict the Commissioner, but I do not believe that we have gone and are moving in the right direction with TTIP and CETA. Greater transparency and democracy means giving everyone access to information; it really means ensuring that human rights are not subordinate to the protection of profits.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank all my fellow Members who have contributed to this report, which has not been an easy job, because, of course, it was a compromise between very different ideas and opinions, including on trade. This evening we have heard people lashing out at free trade and against competition and other people who have emphasised it. I believe that what we managed to do was, however, to give a clear message – and for this I would like to thank you very much for the support we had in the INTA Committee, which I hope to confirm tomorrow – that trade must be understood as a driver of development and well-being in a fair way: not only for European citizens but also for citizens in the rest of the world.  It is true that it is certainly not a Copernican revolution that we have operated with this report but certainly a step in a better direction. Seeing a reality, seeing what is wrong, is not an exercise in great skill. We can all do that. The difference is to start laying the groundwork for something different. We are dealing with an already deeply rooted economy and with already deeply rooted business habits. Our duty and our task is to make improvements. I believe that with these reports – both ours, as far as trade strategy is concerned, and the Forenza report – we have laid the right foundations for taking trade in the desired direction, which is to create greater prosperity and not simply increase trade as a percentage, not knowing who to benefit from.  I would therefore like to thank everyone anyway, and I look forward to a vote tomorrow which is in line.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. Globalisation, if not governed, risks having significant negative effects on social protection standards and employment levels. It is therefore important not to be spectators, and the Eu ropean Union must instead organise itself strategically in order to be proactive. The Commission's trade and investment strategy adopted in 2015 is therefore central, but it must be implemented within the broader framework of a coherent foreign policy. Indeed, trade relations can and must also be an instrument for promoting high standards of safeguarding and promoting human rights, such as social protection and sustainable development. In short, it is essential to be actors and not spectators of the phenomenon.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. – We support the report, and call on the Commission to actively promote further WTO reforms in order to establish multilateral rules for the sustainable and responsible management of global supply chains, including in particular: (a) requirements for effective and idly subject to due diligence of the supply chain and transparency, based on un guiding principles on business and human rights; , (b) health and safety standards, recognising in particular the right of workers in safety committees, (c) a threshold for social protection, (d) respect for the ILO's basic labour standards.  We reiterate our request to ensure that any measure adopted by a Party under the Paris Agreement or on any principle or commitment contained in Articles 3 and 4 of the UNFCCC is also ensured by providing legally better protection of the right to regulate under trade agreements.  Finally, we call on the Commission to accelerate progress in the development of product differentiation systems, depending on their production process and method, as well as sustainability criteria under trade agreements.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. As shadow rapporteur for the S&D Group on the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs in the INTA Committee, I voted from the outset in favour of encouraging the application of social and environmental standards, human rights and corporate social responsibility in international trade agreements, both bilateral and multilateral, ensuring not only ratification but also effective implementation of these standards, in line with the ILO's recommendations. In order to encourage the application of these standards, it is necessary to provide for the possibility of incentives for companies promoting corporate social responsibility (CSR) and considering proactive measures to prevent human or environmental violations, to identify and prevent all violations of human and environmental rights, including with regard to their branches and supply chain. The horizontal introduction of these standards can promote quality work and decent work. The involvement of the social partners in the monitoring mechanism to be implemented by the Commission is essential. RSI can play an important role in ensuring socially and economically sustainable growth, and preventing corruption at European and international level. Finally, I would like to see the gender perspective incorporated into trade policy and greater coordination between EU policies.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. – Considering our support for the 'Trade for All' strategy, presented by the European Commission for the development of a trade policy that is more consistent with the founding values of the European Union and in accordance with the principles of the Group of the Party of European Socialists and Democrats; we welcome the Beghin report. We believe, in fact, that the proposal responds to our call for trade agreements that are more attentive to the protection of the environment and workers' rights, to the objectives of reindustrialisation and to the need, in order to correct its side effects and ensure conditions of fair competition in the commercial arena, to regulate the phenomenon of globalisation. Indeed, we have taken this opportunity to reiterate our opposition to the recognition of China's market economy status. A choice that, due to non-compliance with the required conditions, would pose a serious threat to workers and damage to the competitiveness and sustainability of the European manufacturing system. We also call loudly for the protection of geographical indications in all trade negotiations held by the European Union. Geographical indications, in fact, protecting the historical excellence of the agri-food sector from harmful parasitism even at a reputational level, promote a key sector for the economy of rural areas and strengthen the made in brand.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner Malmström, I would like to thank commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The report on the fight against trafficking in human beings in the EU's external relations is the first of its kind in the European Parliament. It is an own-initiative report by the Subcommittee of the Committee on Human Rights and the Committee on Foreign Affairs, in which we have also incorporated proposals from the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. It has become a very comprehensive, technical report, and I would like to express my sincere thanks to all the colleagues who have contributed to this, as well as to the staff of the committee services.  The forms of these crimes, colloquially referred to as modern slavery, are very different. There are images of wounded people deprived of their freedom, reminiscent of the slaves of a long time gone, for example pictures of men who were detained on fish trawlers, who worked hard there for years under blows and without pay. Or it is about girls who are put into forced prostitution, where, even if they die from it, no one of them, their misery and their suffering, still notices. In our report, however, we also look at less visible forms, such as child soldiers, forced labour in the household, organ trafficking and forced begging. What all these extreme conditions of exploitation have in common is that the victims have been forced and cannot easily free themselves from them. The aim of trafficking in human beings is always the maximum exploitation of the person concerned. In the report, we propose that the EU and also the Member States should focus more intensively on the crimes of trafficking in human beings in a wide range of policy areas. As a matter of urgency, the victims must be brought into the focus of all endeavours. Anyone who wants the perpetrators of this heinous business to be held accountable must give effective witness protection to the victims. They need help, therapy, legal redress of the injustice that has been inflicted on them, they need reparation and compensation. Trafficking in human beings is an enormously lucrative business with human goods. It brings enormous profits to the individual perpetrators and organised crime networks. According to the ILO, forced labour in the private sector generates about USD 150 billion in illegal profits every year. The EU must therefore work more intensively and better with third countries in the information about financial flows. There is a much greater focus on the money laundering machine within the EU. European companies abroad must be accountable for forced labour in their companies and supply chains. In its trade policy, the EU must make every effort to ensure that human rights protection is consistently implemented. A good example was the discussions on the EU-Thailand fisheries trade agreement and slave-like working conditions in Thailand. Europol and the Member States must cooperate better in the fight against organised crime and must not get tangled up in the scrum of competence and demarcation. All those who come into contact with victims of trafficking in human beings, especially border guards and police, must be trained to better identify victims of trafficking. So our report before us lists a large number of measures that the EU can improve. We want to adopt the report tomorrow, and that is the right time to influence this year's review of EU policy against trafficking in human beings with its assessments and demands. I would like to end with a heartfelt thank you to the EU Special Representative and Anti-Trafficking Coordinator, Mrs Vassiliadou, for her outstanding work.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: – The issue of trafficking in human beings, but also an issue that I want to address more, and that is the issue of human trafficking, which has been criminally taken away from people who have been lured to a foreign country, for example, with a job offer, but it was actually slavery, or people trafficked internationally, something that violates even the most basic human rights.  Oftentimes that person also loses his own life, sometimes some organs are only taken away. This is incompatible with how the European Union can enforce respect for human rights in its international activities and in international policy.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – In addition to international aspects, the report emphasises for a reason that trafficking in human beings is also a common phenomenon within the EU. A high proportion of perpetrators are EU citizens and victims are typically women and children. It prompts me to draw renewed attention, without any modesty, to my previous initiative, to institutionalisation of enhanced legal protection for particularly vulnerable victims, such as women, children and the elderly, and to harsher punishment in the justice systems of the Member States. I believe that, among the possible means of reducing trafficking in human beings, it would now also be appropriate to set a more specific objective.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by People smuggling, human trafficking – these are specific issues that we need to ask. I would like to ask the European Commission whether we know what happened to those thousands of children who have gone missing somewhere on immigration routes or already in Europe; whether these children have been trafficked or used to smuggle more people, or the worst has happened to them, something even worse (Mr Mikolášik has just said this) – we still do not know what happened to them. If we want to take such problems seriously, we must seek and demand answers to these questions. Above all, we cannot increase social insuouch. Here in this chamber, mass immigration has been repeatedly called exile. And we know today, and we have just heard from our colleague, how much business has been done about it.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, we all agree that trafficking is not only a grave devaluation of human rights, but also the modern slavery of our times. Allow me, in that light, to remind us that 2015-16 will be remembered as the years when the European Union and European governments failed to respond to the humanitarian needs of refugees and migrants seeking safety in Europe. But these years will also be remembered as years where Europeans accepted that women, men, girls and boys were bought, exploited and treated as commodities. Colleagues, we need to work together. Cooperation and coordination between Member States is crucial when fighting trafficking. Our response has to be clear in order to address the problem by ensuring that victims are also treated as rightsholders as well as we have to stop these criminal gangs on time.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to express my gratitude to the rapporteur. This is an area that is very dear to my heart, also in my former capacity.  The Commission, with the support of the External Action Service, will continue to address human trafficking in the external relations of the European Union. We will continue to ensure that European Union law and standards related to anti-trafficking efforts are properly transposed inside the EU, and we will continue to fight globally for higher standards against human trafficking, bilaterally through different dialogue processes and with leading international organisations. Within the EU, out of the 27 Member States concerned, 26 have now communicated to the Commission full transposition of the Anti-Trafficking Directive. There is one remaining – Germany – and they have informed us about the political agreement reached. We are expecting information very soon on the transposition. An infringement case against this Member State remains open on grounds of non-communication.  The report on the extent to which Member States comply with the directive is foreseen to be presented by the Commission in the fourth quarter of this year. We are currently in the process of developing the post—2016 policy framework, and this resolution and the report are indeed very timely. I would also like to inform you about a milestone the Commission reached recently, at the end of May, with the adoption of the first report assessing the progress made in fighting trafficking in human beings. In this report, we identify areas of progress and achievement, but also expose gaps and efforts that are absolutely still to be made. So the EU has delivered, but a lot remains to be done. We cannot – as all of you have said – allow human beings to be treated like commodities. We must work together to ensure that we prevent the crime from happening, because after that it is too late. We must crack down on trafficking where it matters the most for them – on their profits. There we all have a role to play, including in cooperation with countries beyond EU borders. Trafficking in human beings is indeed part of the European Agenda on Migration, the European Agenda on Security and the new Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy, as well as the new framework for the EU’s activity on gender equality and the empowerment of women in external action 2016-2020.  At the Valletta Summit on Migration, the EU’s and the Member States’ political leaders committed to scale up joint efforts to eradicate trafficking in human beings and combat those who exploit vulnerable people, and that includes children, of course. The action plan that was adopted includes the prevention of, and fight against, irregular migration, migrant smuggling and trafficking in human beings among its priorities.  Trafficking in human beings is also systematically addressed in agreements and partnerships with non-EU countries: in bilateral and regional dialogues on migration and mobility and in political and security dialogues. The EU raises trafficking in human beings in the framework of its human rights dialogue with over 40 countries worldwide, and that is an important component of our action plan on human rights and democracy. We also support international efforts in this field, advocating and funding joint actions with various international regional fora such as the United Nations, the OECE and the Asia Regional Forum. More importantly, we must ensure that we do not foster a culture of impunity for those who exploit and use these victims. We must ensure that the victims are not treated like criminals. We must demand a strong political will and commitment by the leadership of other countries. Only then will the voice and the possible assistance of the EU have an ultimate impact. To do this, we must work together. I count on this Parliament – I know your strong commitment on this issue – to continue to work in this direction. Trafficking in human beings has quite a short story in the external action of the European Union, but we need to do more and to consolidate that work, and this report is an important step in that direction.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 5 July 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – Victims are often ‘invisible people’. They are vulnerable because they are alone, embroiled in a system of abuse, unable to communicate with those outside that system and hidden from authorities who can assist them. This report addresses trafficking in human beings as a transnational crime of a global nature. Consequently it puts forth proposals on how the EU can strengthen the international response to trafficking by focusing on root causes, as well as how it can develop its own foreign affairs and development aid programmes to address the causes that drive persons to fall victim to trafficking networks. We need an EU that addresses transnational organised crime at its source and not only deal with the effects of it in the Member States. This report makes proposals on how the EU can be a leader in doing just that, by engaging third countries to take on board political, social and economic measures that address what leads persons into being trafficked and how the EU must collaborate with third countries to bring international criminal networks down.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – Every 30 seconds another person becomes the victim of human trafficking. Every 30 seconds, another person is ripped away from their families, their friends and their lives and forced into a trade that generates over USD 32 billion a year – a figure which the United Nations estimates could entirely eradicate the global HIV epidemic by 2030. But, while this modern-day slavery is rooted in injustice, inequality and exploitation, the environment within which it resides is fluid, ever changing and adapting to survive. And, while those who exploit vulnerable persons, 50% of them children, take advantage of the world’s changing environment, we are simply unprepared. As the shadow rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on this report, I am highly concerned that international human rights standards are limited in their applicability to situations of climate-induced displacement and that, because of this, persons who are forced to leave their homes and lives due to climate-induced change are becoming increasingly at risk. Without the necessary safeguards or even an established status, these people, who have lost everything, will have no choice but to allow themselves to fall victim to human traffickers.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. – In the context of the fight against trafficking in human beings, I would like to draw attention to the trafficking of human organs, which is one of the ten largest illegal activities of profiteering. However, although there is too little talk about the trafficking of human organs, it is a major problem in some countries and we must not turn a blind eye to it. Slovenia is primarily a transit country for such criminal activities, which is why law enforcement agencies have an increasing responsibility in detecting the activities of criminal groups. The amber alert written statement, signed by by far the highest number of Members in the European Parliament in the last five years, I have sent to the President of the European Parliament, the President and the Interior Minister, to this day, which does not give me optimism that the Slovenian Government is aware of the seriousness of the problem. In fact, 250 000 children are missing in the EU every year, many of them victims of human organ trafficking.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is one-minute interventions on important political issues (Article 163 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: – The European Union is at an important stage. I think that after the British referendum, we have two basic lessons. The first is that populism is a path to an impasse, because populists have won, but they do not know what the next steps are, they do not even know who their leader is, and they do not know what to do next. The second lesson is that people are more aware, both in Britain and in the Union, that we need each other. It is therefore very important that we arrange the best possible relations between the Union and Britain so as to ensure mutual trade, so as to minimise the impact of the damage on the position of Union citizens in Britain. I think it is also important that the projects prepared by the Slovak Presidency, which are important from an economic point of view, continue, and that is: the digital single market, the Energy Union, the Capital Union, precisely because they are important for lowering prices for people and beneficial to all.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Mr President, I wish to record that the Hungarian scandal known as the Quaestor case has been a great failure as far as banking control and supervision are concerned. The Hungarian National Bank failed to effect the necessary interventions before the collapse of this financial pyramid game, leaving tens of thousands of small investors outside of any guarantee or protection schemes. Fatally, thousands of Hungarian small investors turned towards other European asset management companies like the Cypriot IronFX, which appears not to meet its financial obligations. In other words, it operates like a one-way tube, swallowing citizens’ money and trust without any return. I urge the Commission to find specific ways of affording legal protection to citizens who have confidence in a hypothetically well-functioning financial internal market, but who do not have any means of defence in times of trouble, including in relation to criminal cases.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The leadership of the European Commission deceits about the rule of law and itself violates it in relation Polish, to my country. The Treaty on European Union makes it clear: it is the governments of our countries – and only if 22 of them express such an opinion in the European Council – that they can charge some country with violating EU values. The European Commission can only make a proposal on this matter and nothing else. Meanwhile, your interference in the affairs of our country, your conscious or unconscious inflamed political conflict in Poland strikes most at poles with independent views, most hitting those who want to formulate their own position. And this real function is a measure of the real relationship between the European Commission and the leadership of the rule of law, political freedom and democracy.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, sorry to delay proceedings, but is it possible that the list of speakers could appear on the screen as they do for all other debates, so that the next speaker can be ready? That would speed up the process.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: There is no way, this matter has never been done and we are giving the floor in the order of the political groups. Someone from the EPP spoke, someone from S&D spoke, someone from the ECR. We continue in this way, and then the EPP Group's turn comes again and so.m. You are, I believe, the seventh or eighth speakers among the EPP. There are more interventions. That's why, I'm very sorry, it's a purely technical matter.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, Brexit poses many challenges, but without a doubt the country most affected aside from the UK itself will be Ireland. 17% of our exports go to the UK, with a large proportion from our SMEs and our agri-food sector. We also risk the possibility of having a hard border right through the middle of our small island. Ireland will need some kind of temporary or interim regime, or some type of support, if the UK does not have access to the single market. There have been calls for a soft landing for Northern Ireland, for example, but any type of light regime for Northern Ireland while they maintain access to the single market would significantly damage our economy in the Republic. If a business or farmer in Northern Ireland did not have to comply with the same rules – did not have to operate under the same regime as a business or farmer in the Republic – then they would have a huge competitive advantage and we would not be operating on a level playing field. In a balanced way, we in Ireland must strongly defend all our economic interests.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the negative outcome of the British referendum for the European Union underlines the need for a change of course if we do not want to see the unifying process completely derailed in the years to come. A large proportion of European citizens feel alienated from the decision-making processes, while the economic crisis and the policies of bloody austerity have accelerated the impoverishment of those social classes and national economies as a whole, which have in any case had difficulty keeping up with the pace of evolving globalisation.  We urgently need the democratisation of European construction with more and more effective legislative powers for the European Parliament and greater dependence of the European Commission on it. And we need more solidarity, both between the Member States and within societies, with redistribution from the haves to the haves and not vice versa, as is the case today. Dare before it's too late.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Mr President, general elections were held in Spain on 26 June. Three days earlier, authentic recordings had been released in which the Spanish Interior Minister, Jorge Fernández Díaz, conspired precisely with the director of the Anti-Fraud Office to fabricate false and rigged accusations against Catalan politicians favorable to the independence of Catalonia. The enormous gravity of the case did not cause the immediate resignation or dismissal of the minister. Three days later, the election result edested the minister with more votes than before. The conspiratorial minister was awarded by his voters. We Democrats are ashamed that a minister of a supposedly democratic government can still use the methods of Franco's dictatorship. And we're ashamed that there's an electorate who doesn't reject or embarrass him. Can anyone be surprised yet if The Catalan Democrats and Europeanists do not want to participate in a state that accepts and rewards both corruption and espionage against the adversary?

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Mr President, Article 50 is a trap designed to delay and prevent a country leaving the European Union, not to facilitate it. Using it could mean that Britain never leaves the EU or ends up in a place which is almost as bad, such as the Swiss or Norwegian models. A much simpler and quicker method, that of exit, is to do the following: immediately repeal the European Communities Act 1972. This would return supremacy of law-making to our parliament and allow us to immediately enact new legislation to control immigration and borders. All other existing EU directives have been transposed into acts of parliament and would remain in place. Chaos would not ensue. Those acts could then be repealed over a period of time until we are left with the minimum required in order to interact with the European Union. This method puts Britain in control of the process, rather than the European Union.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: – Mr President, the outgoing Prime Minister Cameron played God. There's a saying in my country: be careful what you wish for, because it might happen to you. From this perspective, the vote in the UK referendum has a deeper meaning. Many politicians are torn by the deep feelings of their own people. The effects of Brexit will be of two kinds: in the short and long term. In the short term, the effects are already seen: excessive agitation, statements, conflicting opinions and disputes. These effects will soon fade. We must recognise that Britain has always had an eccentric status in the European Union. Therefore, in the European Union the absence of Britain will not be dramatically felt. The key issue is whether the union leaders and all of us will understand the need for a profound change of substance in the architecture and functioning of the European Union. If so, then the only way is to reform the system completely, quickly and completely. If there is no such reform, and there are no signs that the majority political groups have understood this, then the long-term effects will emerge. And the most important thing is the lack of trust, neither will citizens trust the Union, but politicians will no longer trust each other. The Union will fall apart by perpetuating false and artificial appearances.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: – I am a Member from Slovakia and the Slovak Republic is the Presidency of the European Union this semester. In this context, both journalists and colleagues, politicians in Slovakia, often ask us MEPs what could really be a unique contribution of the Presidency from a post-comminitic country. Which could contribute to the European, our joint work.  I believe that this can also be an alternative proposal to address problems on which citizens and politicians from Eastern Europe have a different view than those from the western part of Europe. Such a priority may be, for example, the submission of comprehensive alternative proposals for the migration crisis. So I stress, now is not the time to criticise divergent views and point the finger at each other or brussels, but also to present meaningful solutions on behalf of the Visegrad Four.

name: Giorgos GRAMMATIKAKIS
text: S&D). Mr President, at this time of year we all remember that Greece was in the constellation of GREXIT. But the Greek government has made a substantial shift towards Europe and cooperation with its institutions. However, as a recent letter from Commissioner Oettinger points out, the same is no longer the case and the government is seeking to systematically overturn the independence of national regulators.  I will give three examples on this subject. Firstly, the licensing framework for television stations is decided, if possible, arbitrarily by the Minister himself. Secondly, there were provocative sanctions by Greek journalists for supporting yes in the referendum. Thirdly, the latest apparent and provocative intrusion by prosecutors and police into a major Greek TV channel.  I therefore call on you all to support the sovereign role of the independent authorities in Greece and throughout Europe.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, the people of the United Kingdom voted to leave the European Union. From the moment the official referendum results were announced, we have heard a lot of angry, outraged and unconstructive comments from people who have important political functions at the European level, and this case has shown that they are not really up to it. Instead of discussing the reasons why the British decided to leave the Union, we allow ourselves heavy words, threats and accusations against each other to fall among our enduring partners. The European Union's crisis as a project cannot be solved by forcing Britons to go as soon as possible to avoid discussing the real reasons for Brexit. In fact, in this way we will only deepen the crisis, because without broad democratic debate and consequent reform, the Union is in for only more discontent, referendums and departures.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr In the wake of the Brexit debate, it is hugely important to be reminded that there are states both in the Balkans and in Eastern Europe that have enormous will to join the EU. This will should be notified; it should be a counterweight and we should help these countries to fulfil the conditions for membership. Bosnia and Herzegovina, for example, has made remarkable efforts in recent years to implement the necessary reforms. Now the issue of the Association Agreement and the census also seems to be resolved. Upon completion, the Slovak Presidency must receive the country's candidate application and give the country official candidate status. We cannot risk these efforts remaining unnoticed, because it will put the Union and Bosnia at risk. That is why I would actually encourage the Commission to show solidarity and attention to countries that are making an effort for membership rather than towards those who do not want to be involved.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – A blackmail and interference manoeuvre is currently underway which affects several sovereign States of the European Union, including Portugal. There is no day without the outgoing statements from European Union officials about the possibility of sanctions on Portugal.  Instead of recognising the complete failure of austerity measures that largely explain the evolution of our public accounts, the European Commission - in an act of pure revanchism - attacks Portugal and its people for having decided to put an end to the austerity programme that led Portugal to disaster. Yes, the 35-hour schedule has been reset, yes, many of the abominable cuts imposed by the Troika have been reversed, namely on wages and pensions, because that was the sovereign will of the Portuguese people who expressed themselves last October.  Not only do we reject sanctions, but we also reject this straitjacket that prevents Portugal and its people from deciding its future. We therefore propose the reversibility of the treaties, the suspension of the budgetary treaty and the repeal of the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Mr President, in this institution, the verse of youth mobility is often recited as a rosary in the hope of finding a job. The European Youth Strategy makes mobility the only passport to employment. In fact, I know that my colleagues in the Commission are keen to take more account of the voice of young people, as highlighted in commissioner Navracsics' A New Story for Europe programme. However, according to Opinionway's youth mobility barometer, in France, 47% of young people aged between 15 and 35 consider mobility a constraint, 65% believe that it is a necessary step to succeed and, finally, 52% of young people surveyed would dream of a fixed place of residence without too much change, further proof that young people do not want your Union of Detached Workers , but they are rooted in a culture, territory and language. Our duty is to enable them to realize these aspirations and to be able to flourish at home, just like migrants elsewhere.

name: Andor DELI
text: – Mr President, although enlargement has been one of the most successful European policies in recent history, there are voices which are calling for a halt to further enlargement of the European Union, especially after the UK referendum. Slowing down the enlargement process or doing it selectively is certainly a short-sighted decision and sends a bad signal to candidate countries like Serbia, which was last week the only candidate state to be deprived of the possibility of opening negotiating chapters. These circumstances only invigorate anti-European forces in the country and are deeply disappointing for citizens, a great majority of whom, according to a recent poll, are  favour of a European future for their country. We all agree that Serbia is a key country in the Western Balkans and can contribute greatly to the success of many European policies, so there must not be any further delays. Today we heard some excellent news from the Paris Conference. Hopefully, we will not see similar delays in the future.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Mr President, we know what the hard blow to the European project and the future of all the British in the referendum a few days ago has meant. But we know that it is time to look forward, to put all our strength into responding to the uncertainty that many European citizens have. There are many European citizens who want to take control, as we heard in the UK referendum, but as we also hear in Greece, in Spain, in Italy, in Germany. In many places there is talk of regaining control.  And we have to say loud and clear that the only way to regain control is to build a truly federal Europe, with a European government capable of managing globalisation, which is capable of putting social policies and a European welfare state on its feet. And may this Parliament be the focus, at the heart of the political debate in Europe.  That is why citizens who want to take control need to know that we need more Europe and a federal Europe.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: – The summer has arrived and with it the forest fires that ravage thousands and thousands of hectares in southern Europe.  In my country, Galicia, we have witnessed the protests of the fire extinguishing staff of SEAGA and The Galician Xunta, who denounce the precarious work in which they find themselves, with contracts of only three months a year.  This is the result of a totally harmful extinction policy that benefits the private company, makes it difficult to fight fires effectively and creates a culture of the fire business.  We believe that the European Union must react on three levels. (1) determine the causes and interests behind the fires caused; 2) Adopt active policies to end the abandonment of the rural environment and promote the installation of farmers and a sustainable forest model; and 3) Ensure a public fire extinguishing service that ends the precarious, insecurity of personnel and dignifies the profession of firecrackers and forest firefighters.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – I would like to talk today about the European Fund for Strategic Investments. The European Commission has published results showing that the EFSI is achieving, to some extent, its purpose. The results are quite encouraging. There is no doubt that investment in infrastructure is very important, but we must not forget about investing in people. It is often felt that investments in society and in the social side of our lives are much underestimated. I believe that, in the context of the EFSI, in view of our demographics, we should also pay more attention to projects in the social field. Last but not least, the social sphere is an area that has long been said to be creating the most jobs in recent times. And, of course, that is why it deserves a special place under the EFSI. I call on the Commission to do something about it.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: – Mr President, I am a young politician who always fights for a better future for Europe. The recent xenophobic outbursts and increased acts of racial violence in the United Kingdom – though not only there – are all signs that an old demon is waking up again. Racism, xenophobia and radicalisation are driven by economic insecurity and underrepresentation, and are being fuelled all the time by populist politicians who would do anything to win a vote. The Leave campaign was a shameful exercise in fear-mongering, but I am convinced that the British did not vote for racism and xenophobia. A handful of racist citizens should never think that they represent the 52% who voted to leave the EU. I call on Parliament, the Commission and the Member States to immediately work with the British Government to protect the rights of all EU citizens living in the UK. Prejudiced views need to change and people need role models. All of the responsible political parties must take a united European stand against racism and xenophobia. Each and every one of us must act. We cannot afford to repeat history.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Mr President, I welcome the fact that on 1 July 2016 the Council prolonged the economic sanctions targeting Russia in response to Moscow’s actions destabilising the situation in Ukraine. In 2015, let me recall, all 28 EU Member States decided unanimously to link the duration of the sanctions to the complete implementation of the Minsk Agreement. For now, however, not only have we not seen any particular improvements in eastern Ukraine, but for the last several days we have heard more about further casualties of attacks of the separatist forces backed by Russia. It is a great surprise for me that from many EU Member States we can now see and hear voices telling us to weaken or even stop sanctions targeting Russia. I call on the Council and the Commission to once more reiterate that any weakening of the sanctions is strictly dependent on the full implementation of the Mink agreements by Russia. On this issue we have to be determined and united. This is a matter for our security.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: Mr President, on 6 May, President Juncker announced the creation of a special envoy for freedom of religion. However, if religious minorities are to be protected, it is equally important to ensure the freedom not to have a religion. The list of countries in which secular activists, atheists and apostates are persecuted is far too long: Yemen, Syria, Qatar, Bangladesh, and we could go on for a long time. For example, last year, a young student was sentenced to three years in prison in Egypt because he declared himself an atheist on Facebook. Moreover, I am concerned that there will be a separation, a division between human rights, yet all indivisible. Freedom of religion should not be considered separately from other fundamental rights because, in some contexts, religion itself is an obstacle to the exercise of certain rights: sexual and reproductive rights, LGBT rights, gender equality. That is why, in the context of this Special Envoy, we are calling for clear guidelines to avoid the establishment of parallel religious diplomacy and to ensure the defence of fundamental rights without exception.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, I would like to use this possibility to wish happiness and long life to His Holiness the Dalai Lama on the occasion of his 81st birthday in two days’ time. The earthly manifestation of the Buddha to Tibetan Buddhists, His Holiness is also a source of wisdom and compassion for many of us here in Europe. He is the living example of the spiritual power needed for peaceful resistance. After more than 50 years in exile, he has been consistently calling for non-violent resistance, as the only way to achieve autonomy for his people. This is all the more admirable if we think of all the sufferings Tibetans go through. Silence is sometimes the best answer, says the Dalai Lama. However, I am hopeful that in the future this House will not follow this advice when dealing with the mistreatment of his people. This would be the best way to honour the life-long struggle of His Holiness.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: – Mr President, I would like to start by thanking all of those who campaigned and voted for the UK to remain in the European Union. We are the 48 percent who value our European friends and neighbours, who value our solidarity with those we share a continent with and, above all, value the most successful peace process the world has ever known, particularly as we commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Battle of the Somme.  Eleven days after the vote, it appears that the leave campaign had no plan. Currently, leading Leave protagonists are resigning, taking no responsibility for the mess that they have created. You could not make this up. We should never forget those who got us into this disaster. Meanwhile, the urgent need to reassure those who are EU citizens in the UK, by the UK Government and by other EU institutions, that they have a guaranteed legal status is absolutely vital. We must do all that we can to seek clarity at this difficult time.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, the fallout from Brexit is fast and furious: sterling down to a 30-year low, a AAA rating gone, Scotland talking about leaving, and in Ireland we have our problems because the United Kingdom is our closest ally and our biggest trading partner. The European Union spent millions helping to create peace in Northern Ireland. If the hard border is re-introduced, there is a danger it will play into the hands of extremism and all that good work could be undone again. For this, we can thank three people in particular: the three Musketeers – dithering David, bluffing Boris and ferocious Farage. They could not stop putting the boot into Europe, but now their legacy is that they have put the ‘dis’ into the United Kingdom – disunited geographically, generationally and politically. For that, I think they should get a special award, and the award I would give them is the ‘wrecking ball’ award. I could not think of three people who deserve it more.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after Brexit, 2016 is the time when concepts such as two-speed Europe or Western and Eastern Europe must disappear. A first step towards strengthening a homogeneous route of the 27 would be to rethink the distribution of the Union institutions in the territory, which would give a clear signal that the Union is giving equally important roles to all Member States. One of the arguments of anti-Europeans, at least in the states that came to the Union after 1990, is that the Union means the domination of western European nations over others. Countering this current must be done with facts, and the homogeneous distribution of the Union institutions throughout the EU is a first step. In this respect, I would like to make a proposal here: after Brexit, Romania becomes statistically the sixth nation of the European Union. In this context, I believe that the time has come for the European Union to show Romanians that it trusts them and their administrative capacity by reallocating to Romania the European Medicines Agency, which is currently based in London. In the next period I intend to generate a legislative proposal in this regard, and I hope that you will be with me, so that together we can give a signal of European unity to both Romanians and other nations.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, I would like to mention an important subject here. Although we have been talking about it for a long time, Commissioner, it is not and has not been adequately addressed. Few people realise that turning kilometres is one of the biggest problems that is plaguing consumers in the European Union.  Experts estimate that more than 30% of used cars in the European Union are affected by this problem. Consumers then lose more than €9 billion a year because of these unfair practices. Fraudsters profit at the expense of society as a whole. And the European Parliament, which represents this whole, should do everything in its power to protect citizens. After all, customers have the right to know the actual status of the kilometers they decide to purchase. I therefore ask you, Commissioner, to push for systemic legislative changes in this area.

name: Esther HERRANZ GARCÍA
text: – Mr President, this is the symbol of the Actays association. Today I am speaking in one step further of Actays' challenge in the world to raise sensitivity and give visibility to rare diseases, especially those related to gangliosidosis: Tay-Sachs and Sandhoff. This year is important because of scientific findings, which are about to start saving the lives of children affected by these diseases, and these studies are developed from the University of Cambridge. For Meritxell, a six-year-old Riojan girl, and for all the other children who like her are struggling to survive, I ask that anyone who can collaborate collaborate, even financially, and do as much as they can for them, and that from this Parliament we help them by supporting scientific advancement and gene therapies that give these children struggling to live and their families an opportunity.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: This item on the agenda has been closed.
